Sir,

I have the honour to enclose herewith attached, Report of Provisions used at John Smith's Day School during the month of June, 1922.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir,

I beg to inform you that about three months ago, Mr. J. L. Lowe, teacher of the school on John Smith's Reserve, requested to be transferred to the school on James Smith's reserve, Fort a la Corne. The reasons he gave were that the people were dissatisfied and that he himself felt that his work was not satisfactory. I had some conversation with Mr. Lowe, but I did not see my way to make any representation to your Department at the time. Now however matters seem to have reached a stage when some action is necessary. The Indians have sent a petition to the Bishop of Saskatchewan, complaining that their children are not making any progress and requesting a change of teachers.

I would therefore respectfully enquire, Would the Department consider it advisable to carry out an exchange between Mr. Goodman and Mr. Lowe? Also, are the stipends the same at each of these two schools? I have no doubt the change would be an advantage to the John Smith's school. As you are no doubt aware, Mr. Lowe taught the South La Corne school for some time before it was closed.

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

J. A. Mackay

Russell T. Ferrier Esq.
Supt. of Indian Education
Ottawa
Ottawa, August 18, 1922.

Very Reverend Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, informing the Department that Mr. J. L. Lowe, Teacher of the school on the John Smith's Reserve, requests to be transferred to the school on the James Smith's Reserve, and stating the reasons for desiring this exchange.

In reply I beg to say that there would be a difficulty in making this exchange. Mrs. Lowe is Field Matron, and her position has been established by the Civil Service Commission. If this transfer were made and her services retained, it would be necessary to have the position of Field Matron for the James Smith's Reserve established by the Civil Service Commission. The Department has not considered the appointment of a field matron for this last named reserve.

The salary allowed Mr. Goodman is at the rate of $750 per annum plus bonus; the salary paid Mr. Lowe is $600 per annum plus bonus and Mrs. Lowe, as Field Matron, $430 plus bonus.

In view of the above, the Department does not consider it advisable at the present time to arrange an exchange in positions between Mr. Goodman and Mr. Lowe, without some stronger reason being given therefor than has been up to this time set forth.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Ven. Archdeacon J. A. MacKay,
Synod Office
Prince Albert,
Sask.

Sir,

I have the honour to report that about one month ago Mr. J.L. Lowe, teacher of the John Smith's reserve Day School, met with an accident, hurting his knee, when his horse ran away on his return to the reserve from Prince Albert. When I visited the reserve on the 12th instant, I found Mr. Lowe was walking lame and had a swollen knee. I advised him to lay up for a while and get proper treatment.

I am today in receipt of a communication from Mrs. Lowe, which reads,

"I am writing to let you know Mr. Lowe is sick. He went to doctors on 19th & had his leg lanced; now he has to go in again today, he has another place to be lanced. Dr said he was not to take school but lie and rest. Will do reports as soon as able."

The reports referred to by Mrs. Lowe are the Quarterly School Returns for the quarter ending Sep. 30th, 1922.

I have hopes that Mr. Lowe will soon be able to resume his duties.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

CPS/B.
OTTAWA, November 14th, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 2nd instant, informing the Department that Mr. J. L. Lowe, teacher of the John Smith's Indian Day School, had met with an accident which necessitated his giving up duties as teacher.

In reply I beg to say that the accident to Mr. Lowe is regretted, and it is hoped that he will soon have recovered sufficiently to resume duties.

A return showing the days taught, etc., for the quarter ending September 30th, should be prepared by Mr. Lowe as soon as he is able to do so and forwarded through your office. In preparing his return for the current quarter, he should clearly state thereon the dates between which the school was closed on account of his accident. This is necessary in order that payment of his salary can be allowed for the time he was unable to teach.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

C. Paul Schmidt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Duck Lake, Sask.

September 15th, 1923

Russell J. Perrier, Esq.
Supt. of Indian Education,
Ottawa.

Sir,

I am writing concerning the John Smith's Day School in the Duck Lake Agency, Sask. There has been signed eight applications for entrance of pupils of this school to the Indian Boarding Schools.

Seven of these have been approved by the Dept., one pupil has already gone without approval of the Dept. Two more applications are awaiting medical certificates before sending them in for approval. There is also one more pupil of this school for whom application is to be made for; think if all these applications for entrance to the Boarding School is approved, it will leave me with so few scholars that when the cold weather comes there will be only one or two who will come to school, and I am sure that the school cannot keep open as the few that will be left with me will be too small to come.

I am so placed now that I ask through you that, if this school is closed, or about to be closed, would the Indian Dept. give me another position as teacher elsewhere. I have been teaching here four years. Previous to this I was at the South Forte No. One Day School six years. Report of the school
was given last October by School Inspector Mr. Tomlinson of Prince Albert.

I would like to have a position in the Day School, but if not possible, I would teach in a Boarding School.

I have worked conscientiously in this work and like it and do not wish to go out of the Indian work.

I remain

Yours obediently,

J. L. Lowe
Teacher.
Ottawa, Oct. 2, 1923.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 15th ultimo, in which you inform the Department that the John Smith's Indian Day School will be left with very few pupils, if active recruiting is continued for the boarding schools. I have noted that you would be willing to accept a transfer to another day school, in the event that the Department decides activities should cease at the present school.

I should be pleased if you would continue your efforts for the time being, and not only assist recruiting officers to secure children for residential schools, but make a special effort to have your own enrolment the best possible. If, in the course of the winter, we find the John Smith's Day School should be closed, because of lack of pupils, I shall be pleased to bend every energy to secure another day school, under Church of England auspices, for you.

Your obedient servant,

Russell F. Ferrier
Supt. of Indian Education.

J. L. Lowe, Esq.,
John Smith's Reserve,
Davis P. O., Sask.

Ottawa.
Ottawa, October 30, 1923.

Sir,

In a recent report on the John Smith School, Inspector Hutchison makes the following suggestions which the Department trusts you will bear in mind and put into effect:

(1) - The teacher should think well of what he wishes to accomplish in his school and then organise his work to accomplish it.

(2) - Reading, literature and story telling should be stressed.

(3) - The activities of the children should be more called into play.

(4) - Oral work with a view to training in thinking and expression is required in all grades.

(5) - Special attention should be given to the quality of voice, as at present pupils read and speak in a mumbling tone.

(6) - More attention should be given to training in habits of neatness and order.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,

J. L. Lowe, Esq.,

SASK.
Sir:

The Indian houses on John Smith's Reserve appear to be very comfortable and the premises surrounding were clean.

The school on this Reserve is not doing good work. Mr. and Mrs. Lowe are by no means energetic and although there is excellent opportunity of doing good work they appear to have got into a rut. Mr. Lowe complained that his garden was full of sow thistle and that he was not able to do much with it. The whole garden could be ploughed in half an hour and the thistles growing there could be hand picked.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

DIocese OF SASKATCHEWAN

The Right Rev. George Exton Lloyd, D.D.

Bishopsthorpe

Prince Albert, Sask.

Friday, August 24th, 1925.

Re John Smith's Reserve.

Dear Mr. McLean:

Since writing you on August 18th with reference to Mr. Gentleman's name being submitted for the new school on Big Heads Fort a la Corne Mission, the enclosed letter has come in from John Smith's Reserve.

For the last two years every missionary going to this reserve had been greeted with the request that Mr. Lowe be removed. I had this in full measure last year but after hearing all that was to be said I took no action.

But it is quite evident that Mr. Lowe has lost the confidence of the Indians. There does not appear to be anything wrong in the man, but he seems to have got on the wrong side of the Indians altogether and they don't want him there.

I don't think his resignation ought to be asked for without further trial and I would suggest that he might be given an exchange to Big Head and let Mr. Gentleman come to John Smith's reserve. If that were done, Mr. Gentleman would be within easy driving distance of Prince Albert in case his wife needed attention.

If, for any reason known to the Department, this is not advisable, would you consider Mr. Lowe's name for the Red Earth vacancy?

I put the matter in this tentative way because I do not know whether there is any adverse report of Mr. Lowe's work in the Department. If so, it would be better to let him go because he is doing no good at John Smith's.

Believe me to be,

Yours very faithfully,

G. E. Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, August 28, 1925.

Dear Bishop Lloyd:

With further reference to Your Lordship's letter of the 16th instant and in reply to yours of the 21st instant, concerning teaching services at the Fort a la Corne South and John Smith Indian Day Schools, I have to state that the Department cannot give approval to the appointment of Mr. F. H. Gentleman at either school. This teacher taught at the John Smith School a few years ago, and, after a study of the files and knowing something of Mr. Gentleman's own wishes, it is considered most unwise to offer him an Indian school in what is known as our Duck Lake agency. When Mr. Gentleman was in Ottawa, on his way to England, he informed the Superintendent of Indian Education that, if he were not nominated for The Pas School, he would prefer to teach in Eastern Canada. There will be an opening in an Ontario undenominational Indian day school in October and I cabled to him yesterday, offering the position.

I note Your Lordship's remarks concerning Mr. Lowe, the present incumbent at John Smith's. I hesitate to approve of the transfer of Mr. Lowe to either Fort a la Corne South or Red Earth. At these two schools there would be no stipend for Mrs. Lowe as field matron and a transfer would mean a considerable financial loss to Mr. and Mrs. Lowe. The public school inspector and our own officers have lately reported more favourably concerning this teacher's services, and, in view of the fact that the beginning of the school year is only a few days away, I feel it would be wiser to allow Mr. Lowe to continue at John Smith's for another year, on further trial, and to secure a new incumbent for the re-opened Fort a la Corne South Indian Day School.

Yours very truly,

J. D. McLEAN

J. D. McLean,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General.

Rev. G. H. Lloyd, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Sir,

Referring to my transfer to another reserve, I have received a letter from the Chairman of Bishop Lloyd's Commission under date of Aug 14th, an extract from the letter here follows:

"Since writing you I have seen the Bishop and talked matters over regarding Red Earth. It is the Bishop's wish now that you should remain where you are until Christmas, and after that perhaps go to Montreal Lake." Another extract reads:

"Mr. Waite who was expecting to go to John Smith's will probably go to Fort A in the meantime. This arrangement will give time for further consideration of all matters involved, and doubtless by Christmas some satisfactory arrangement will be arrived at."

I have now received a letter from the Indian Agent, Mr. Schmidt, Esq., under date of Aug 9th which reads: "I am in receipt of a communication from the Department informing me that the Rev. G. J. Waite has been appointed teacher of the John Smith's Day School, duties to commence on Sep 1st next. Will you please let me know when you intend moving out..."

As I have not received word from your Department direct, I would like to know what I am to do. The arrangements seem to have got muddled up somehow, and my wife and I are both anxious.

I remain

Your obedient servant,
John L. Lowe.

In answer to your letter No. 107-5-1 under date of August 1926 re. the reopening of Mistawasis Indian Day School.

I wish to say that the reason I wrote the Dept. was that during an interview with Bishop Lloyd the first week in May 1926, His Lordship told me that it was his intention to transfer me to the Mistawasis school, that this school was to have been closed, but that arrangements had been made, and the school would now be kept open. This was satisfactory to me.

I heard a week later from a young clergyman that the school was definitely closed. On June 3rd I went to see one of the clergymen on the Bishop's Indian Committee. I asked him as to the closing of the Mistawasis school and he said, "The school will be kept open, arrangements have been made, and you are to go there."

The second week in July one of the clergymen of the Bishop's Commission called on me, and asked me to decide on one of two places offered, Mistawasis or Red Earth. I said Mistawasis, as I had been told by the Bishop it was his intention that I go there, also I knew nothing about Red Earth.

A week later I received a letter from the Chairman of the Bishop's Commission, that Mistawasis school was definitely closed, and that I have been nominated for Red Earth, and a request that I write him. I wrote him asking for more information about Red Earth, saying that if this meant setting up my home, and travelling many miles out of civilization, the thought was not very pleasant especially with two young children.

"Since writing you I have seen the Bishop and have talked matters over regarding Red Earth. It is the Bishop's wish now that you should remain where you are until Christmas, and after that perhaps go to Montreal Lake to relieve Reverend who is probably going back to England."

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just returned to Prince Albert after a long round of the Indian missions of the North, extending from June the 24th to May. May I take up the points of some of these missions with you.

1. John Smith's Reserve. I have had another visit of a deputation from John Smith's asking for the exchange or removal of their teacher, Mr. Lowe. As I wrote you more than a year ago, I am quite satisfied this man's usefulness on that reserve has come to an end some time ago, and it would have been much better had the Indian Agent's recommendation to continue him for another year not been followed. Not only are they dissatisfied with his teaching and his influence on the children but it is now become a matter of real grievance. Since meeting Mr. Lowe on the train the other day I am very loath to recommend him for any other Indian mission. His nature seems to be like steel rails. He has no qualifications as a teacher and he seems to be of a hard unsympathetic nature. I had suggested to him the mission of Red Earth on the Carrot River, but he thought himself entirely too good for that. However that offer is not now available.

2. Red Earth. Mr. and Mrs. Ash both request to be continued as teacher in the Red Earth Reserve until the end of next June at least, and I have promised to endorse and send in this request. I understood they wanted to leave but they are now anxious to take this next year's school work until June 30th 1927. Mr. Ash and his wife are both fully qualified and certificated teachers.

3. Montreal Lake. I am afraid Mr. Pereira and his wife will be giving up this school at Christmas. I talked things over very fully with him because he has been such a splendid success and those children in the school are totally different from what I saw before. He wants to return to England on account of the teachers' pensions. I greatly regret their going. This might be an opening for Lowe of John Smith's if one could be sure that he did not let the work down, and it is the only opening that I can see at the present time.
4. Lac La Ronge. Everything here seemed to be going as usual and as far as I could judge quite satisfactorily.

5. Stanley. The young teacher Mr. Strong seems to be doing very well at that summer school with the assistance of the Rev. Canon Paul. There is still the open question about the teacher last year, Mr. Taylor, carrying on the summer school right over into the Winter and early Spring. He claims that he had the recognition of the Indian Agent, and he thought the support of the Indian Department, and thinks that it depended wholly on the willingness of the Indians to keep their children there, he carried on. Of course he has had nothing but the Summer stipend and feels that he has a strong grievance against the Department, and has made no return of the money the Synod advanced to him to make the journey up there. I was in England at the time or I should have questioned his staying there long before I did, but he seems to have acted in a bone fide way, though the letters of the Department to our Synod Office gave no authority for anything but the summer school.

6. Pelican Narrows. We spent the greater part of a day in this school inspecting their writing, drawing, nature study, singing and a very little reading. They seemed to be getting all that is possible in the short time, but are decidedly behind the children at Stanley.

7. The Pas Day School. Everyone appeared to have a good word for the progress of the children in this day school under Mr. Humberstone. Missionaries and Indians agreed that the children were doing very well and one Indian father drew detailed comparison between his boy in the day school and the other boy in the residence school, and not to the credit of the residence school. I do not think that should be taken for anything more than satisfaction with what was going on in the new day school.

8. Big Eddy Day School. I had a large deputation of the Indians including the Chief and all the councillors urging me to apply to the Department for a new school to replace the old log thing that Miss Millan has at Big Eddy. From all accounts the rain gets in and the mud smells badly, besides seeping out continually, and altogether the building is disreputable. All agreed with the missionary that Miss Millan's work was thoroughly good and clearly her influence is most marked on the Indians as well as thoroughly good teaching work with the children. She seems to put her whole heart into the work and I would strongly urge that a new school like Humberstone's should be built there. I ought to add that the opening of these two day schools there has had a very marked effect on the whole Devon Mission, it was a good stroke of work when those schools were opened.

9. Moose Lake. The Rev. Mr. Parker and his wife have taken possession of this mission and school. As you know the wife is a fully qualified teacher and is herself an Indian graduate.
of the Lac la Ronge Boarding School. She has been accepted by the Educational Department of Manitoba but of course there are the Indian children in connection with it as well.

Mr. Waite and his wife have moved up to Fort la Corne mission until Mr. Smith's school is vacated. Mr. Waite, as you probably know, has his B.A. and his first class teaching certificate, and has been very successful in his work amongst the non-English foreigners before he took up the Indian school work. In the meantime I am finding him temporary employment at Fort la Corne.

10. Cedar Lake. I was very glad to see the new log house that has been put up at this point for the teacher and his wife. It is a great improvement on the old log affair that was there before.

11. Grand Rapids Village. Mr. Horsefield is moving down from Pelican Narrows at the close of his engagement there in September to take this school. It is of course under the Manitoba Government but is just about as Indian as the reserve on the other side of the river. Mr. Horsefield is a highly qualified teacher and will be a help and companion to the teacher on the reserve opposite.

12. Grand Rapids Reserve. I found everyone here has a good word to say for Mr. Wyatt. His wife and two boys joined him this summer coming via Winnipeg, and they are a thoroughly nice family with two well behaved little boys. I had no opportunity to inspect the school children but everyone seemed to be pleased with the progress made. The house however is quite unsatisfactory. The building itself is log and built backwards road to the lake front. The inside is quite unfinished and unfit for anyone to live in as it is. I found all his winter supplies and all the new mission furniture in the new school building where they are living, and after going carefully into the whole matter, I instructed him to stay where he was in the new school building until his house was properly finished and if necessary have the desks moved up to the old school building until the house was ready. Who is to blame for this I do not wish to say but a little checking up of the Indian Agent in Winnipeg would not do any harm. That Reserve is a very isolated one during seven months of the year and when we do get a really good teacher for places like that we want to keep them satisfied.

13. I did not visit any of the schools in the Cumberland lake area although I was there for the purposes of the missions and the Barrier and Budds Point are of course provincial schools.
I should be glad to hear from you with regard to the suggestion of Mr. Lowe transferring from John Smith's to Montreal Lake at Christmas, and if so then Mr. Waite's name will stand in nomination for John Smith's together with Mrs. Waite as matron.

Believe me to be

Yours very faithfully,

September 28, 1926.

Dear Bishop Lloyd:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, concerning the Indian missions of Your Lordship's diocese and with particular reference to the Indian day schools. I am very pleased to learn that satisfactory progress is being made generally and I wish to assure you that the Department will cooperate in effecting improvements whenever a school gives reasonable promise of success. I hope that Your Lordship will be in Ottawa in the not distant future and that we can have an interview regarding the future of the work.

I note that Mr. Lowe will have to leave the John Smith School, as he has outlived his usefulness on the reserve. The appointment of the Rev. G. J. Waite to this school as from January first has already been approved by the Department. Your Lordship might suggest that Mrs. Waite apply for the position of field matron. She should indicate what domestic duties she has and how much time could be given to visiting.

I learn with regret that Mr. and Mrs. Pereira are leaving the Montreal Lake Indian Day School. Mr. Pereira taught this school during August and has permission to close on November 30th. This should be kept in mind when Your Lordship is arranging for a successor. If you wish to try Mr. J. L. Lowe at Montreal Lake I shall be glad to approve when the definite nomination is to hand.

I have directed that letters be sent to Your Lordship concerning the other questions that need attention.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Rt. Rev. G. E. Lloyd, D. D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert,

JOHN SMITH'S INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is in charge of the Rev. Gilbert Waite who is a University graduate and holds his 1st Class Professional.

The roll calls for 15 and I found 11 present. The grades range as follows:

Grade I - 6
" III - 2
" IV - 4
" V - 1
" VI - 2

The attendance for September was 8.1, which is rather low. Mr. Waite has experienced considerable difficulty in having the children attend. I took this up with the Indians and pointed out that the children must attend unless sick, otherwise it will be necessary to place them
JOHN SMITH'S INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

place them in boarding schools. The Agent is giving this matter closer attention, and I would expect to find the attendance improve.

The children are making fair progress, and I found them to be clean and well clothed.

A noon-day meal is served by Mrs. Waite, composed of soup, vegetables and biscuits. A splendid garden was raised this year, so there will be abundance of vegetables for the children.

Each child is provided with a drinking cup, towel and tooth brush, all of which are made use of.

I found the outside windows all fastened on, preventing any fresh air coming in except through a couple of inch holes at the bottom of the sash. Some of these sash should be on hinges, and the inside windows should be fixed to open from the top so as to prevent a direct draft on the children.

The school yards have been re-fenced, and I found everything in a neat and tidy condition. Mr. Waite is a good worker, not only in the classroom, but outside, and the condition of the place is a credit to him.

I beg to forward herewith a very satisfactory report on the schools in the Duck Lake Agency, comprising three day schools and one Residential school.

At the John Smith's Day School the work seems to be carried on under a capable teacher. The attendance here is highly satisfactory. It is pleasing to note that here too, where we have no resident Farming Instructor, the children were found to be well clothed and neat in appearance.

JOHN SMITH'S INDIAN DAY SCHOOL

This school is in charge of the Rev. G. J. Waite, a university graduate, and he also holds his First Class professional certificate. Mr. Waite is doing excellent work and the children are making good progress.

The roll calls for 18 pupils, and 16 were present. The attendance has been excellent, and for January was over 92%. The children appeared greatly interested in their work, and I found for the quarter ending January 31st, that 6 pupils had not missed a day during the quarter. The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 8      |
| II    | 4      |
| III   | 1      |
| IV    | 1      |
| V     | 3      |
| VI    | 1      |

The children were well clothed and neat in appearance. They have individual towels, which are made use of and each is provided with cup and tooth brush.

A noon-day meal is served, and this is well prepared by Mrs. Waite, who also does the Field Matron's work on the reserve.

A new garden was ploughed and made ready for this year, so that now the children can be kept in the school ground. It has, in the past, been the custom to use the school ground as a garden, and the children were obliged to play across the road. The new arrangement will be much better and will be safer for the children.

The pupils assist in the planting and caring for the garden, and the vegetables are used in the winter for the noon-day meal. The girls are taught knitting.
JOHN SMITH'S INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

knitting and plain sewing by Mrs. Waite, and do some very nice work.

I feel the Department are fortunate in the securing of Mr. Waite as teacher. Mrs. Waite does excellent work as Field Matron.

Dear Mr. Schmidt:

I am sorry that I was away when you called the other day. I am travelling constantly now.

The Bishop arrived this afternoon, and I consulted him about Mr. Waite and a possible temporary teacher.

We found out that Mrs. Waite has done some temporary teaching and that she would be willing to carry on the work while her husband is sick. The Bishop therefore recommends that this suggestion be submitted to Ottawa for the approval of the Department. Would you be willing to make this suggestion in your report?

Dr. Bliss said that he could not tell yet how long it would be before Mr. Waite would be able to carry on his work again, but he would need a rest for some time.

Signed W.E.J. Paul.
Duck Lake, Sask.
March 26th, 1935

Rev Sir:

When at Prince Albert yesterday I called at your office but was informed you were out of town.

The object of my call was to discuss with you the matter of having someone take Rev Mr Waite's place as teacher at the John Smith's Reserve Day School, during his Mr Waite's illness.

Dr Bliss informs me that Rev Mr Waite underwent a serious operation and from this I take it that he will not be able to resume his work teaching for some time.

I do not know whether Mrs Waite could, or would, care to carry on the class-room work, nor do I care to write to her re same. I understand the school is closed at the present time.

I shall await your reply before reporting to the Department.

Signed C.P. Schmidt,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, July 3rd, 1940.

Dear Sirs:

With reference to your letter of the 26th ultimo, you may inform Rev. G. J. Waite that his resignation as teacher of the John Smith's Indian Day School is accepted. It is understood that this resignation was effective from June 30th, 1940.

As this school is conducted under Anglican auspices, we would appreciate if you would consult the Bishop of Saskatchewan with a view to having him nominate a qualified teacher to take charge of this school during the academic year 1940-41.

Salary allowed is at the rate of $80 a teaching month and as you are aware the school will be open for a nine months' period during the academic year 1940-41.

You should advise me later regarding the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher nominated by the Bishop.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Re John Smith's Indian Day School.

In the absence of the Bishop of Saskatchewan I am writing you with regard to above School. You will have heard that the Rev. R.M. Luckraft has sent in his resignation as Teacher in order to take another position under the Government.

We are doing our best to find another Teacher, but there is a great scarcity of Teachers, and many white schools in this district are now closed on this account. I have heard of one lady Teacher who may be available; but I am afraid we may not be able to find a man.

In the meantime Mrs. Luckraft is willing to carry on the School till a successor can be found. Mr. Simpson, the Indian Agent, tells me that this arrangement will be acceptable to the Department for a few weeks.

I may point out that the salary at this School has been $80 per teaching month, or $720 per annum, whereas most of the other Schools have been allowed $90 or $95. John Smith's is one of the best Indian Day Schools, and the average attendance is very high, and I should like to suggest that the salary be made the same as most of the other Schools.

The Bishop is at present in Eastern Canada, and he is looking out for more workers, and it is possible that he might find another clergyman who is also a teacher to make Mr. Luckraft's place. I know he will do his best in this matter.

Yours faithfully,

W. L. J. Paul.
Dear Sir,

With reference to Departmental letter No. 109-5-1 dated September 21st., I beg to report that I interviewed Archdeacon Paul at Prince Albert yesterday in connection with procuring a teacher at the John Smiths Indian Day School.

Archdeacon Paul informed me that it is most difficult to procure the services of teachers for Indian Day Schools under the present circumstances. He also stated that the salary offered at this school was lower than that being paid by the Department at any of the other Indian Day Schools in this part of the Province despite there being more work at the John Smiths School owing to the average attendance of pupils there being higher than at most of the other schools. If this is the case I would recommend that if possible an adjustment be considered in the rate of salary for teaching at this school. I have found that the members of the John Smiths Reserve give much better co-operation in having their children attend school than is the case on any other reserve in this Agency excepting the Moose Woods Sioux.

Archdeacon Paul informed me that at present there was no one in view to fill the vacancy as teacher of this school, but that he had every hope of being able to procure a teacher by October 31st. and requested that Mrs. Luckraft be employed to carry on with this work until that date. Mrs. Luckraft is capable of doing so and in view of the circumstances I have requested her to open the school on October 1st., with the understanding that she will be relieved of this work by the end of that month.

Yours very truly,

S. H. SIMPSON
INDIAN AGENT.

Information for Purchasers of Canada's War Savings Certificates

Date of Issue. War Savings Certificates will be dated the fifteenth of the month in which payment is completed. For example, whenever in any one month your Total Salary Deductions are sufficient to buy your War Savings Certificate, that Certificate will bear the date of the 15th of that month.

Registration. Each War Savings Certificate is registered at the Bank of Canada, Ottawa. Registration will be made in one name only. A War Savings Certificate is not transferable and cannot be redeemed other than by its registered owner. Provision is made for redemption in case of the death of a holder.

Care should be taken to state clearly the name and address in which you desire Certificates registered. Spell out the first or Christian name in full, as well as the surname, and give proper prefix (Mr., Mrs., or Miss).

For example: Correct—BROWN, MR. KENNETH D.

A married woman must furnish her own Christian name and surname.

For example: Correct—WHITE, MRS. MARGARET E.

Incorrect—Mrs. Henry G. White.

Purchase Limit. No person may hold War Savings Certificates in excess of a purchase value of $500 purchased in any one calendar year. That is to say, you may purchase $500 worth this year, and up to a like amount in each succeeding year.

Income Tax. Due to the difficulties of calculation, the small amounts involved and the limited individual holdings, holders will not be required to report the difference between the purchase price and the redemption value of War Savings Certificates, as income in making returns under the Income War Tax Act.

Redemption. War Savings Certificates cannot be called for redemption until they have matured to their date of maturity. The holder, however, has the option six months after issue date of redeeming his certificates for cash, and after the first year will also be paid interest to the date of redemption in accordance with the table of redemption values shown on each certificate. The Minister of Finance reserves the right to require ninety days' notice in the case of redemption before maturity.

Mr. Simpson, Indian Agent, Duck Lake Agency, was paying Treaty I accompanied the Treaty party to the different reserves in this Agency with the exception of Moose Woods Sioux.

Regarding day schools in this Agency, of course when I visited the different reserves to pay Treaty the schools were naturally closed and as a man from the San and Dr. Morrow were X-raying all of the Indians the schools were being used for this purpose. However, I must say I am not very much taken up with the work that is being carried on at these schools at the present time. For instance there is a Mrs. Roberts teaching at the day school on the John Smith Reserve. The Agent informed me this teacher is not capable and evidently the Church has promised him she will be replaced. There is an Indian girl teaching at the For-a-lla-Corne Indian Day School and I believe she is a very good teacher but the daily attendance is very poor, being only 12. At the day school on the south end of the reserve where Mr. Ahenakew is teaching the average attendance is only 9. Therefore I consider we are not receiving the attendance we might expect, and I spoke to everybody concerned, that is the Agent, Farming Instructor, etc. The attendance at John Smith Bay School, of course is good but as I stated above, it is very poor at the other two schools mentioned and I expect to be up in that vicinity again later on in the Summer at which time I will talk to the Indians and the school teachers some more.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

M. Christiansen, Esq., General Superintendent of Agencies, Regina.

I beg to report that the services of Mrs. M. Roberts, Teacher at the John Smiths Indian Day School, has not been found satisfactory.

She is unable to maintain proper discipline over the school children, especially during recess and mid day periods. The lack of discipline is also apparent in her home. I have been given to understand from a reliable source that her eldest daughter had been keeping company with one of the young members of the reserve and had entertained him in her home. I have since been advised that the daughter is now living away from home.

The teacher's husband, Mr. Roberts, has given up the work he was employed at and has been living on the reserve with his wife. He appears to be a lazy type of individual.

Mrs. Roberts does not appear to be capable of leading or instructing the women of the Homemaker's Club in their work on this reserve.

It is realized that under present conditions it is difficult to procure suitable teachers for this particular and important type of work among the Indians. However it is felt that if possible a more suitable teacher should be employed on this reserve.

While at Prince Albert yesterday I interviewed the Right Reverend H.D. Martin, Bishop, and the Venerable W.E.J. Paul, Archdeacon, pertaining to this matter. Bishop Martin advised that he was under the impression that teachers could not be given notice that their services were no longer required during the school holidays and requested that the Department advise him as soon as possible as to its wishes in this case.

S. H. Simpson  
Indian Agent.

P.S. While paying Treaty at the John Smiths Reserve I advised...
you that Bishop Martin had agreed to have another teacher appointed in Mrs. Robert's place at the beginning of the next school term. I brought this matter to his attention on June 4th, when he then advised me that Archdeacon Paul had visited Mrs. Roberts and on his return had advised him that Mrs. Roberts had improved in her work and should now prove satisfactory. I advised the Bishop that her services were not satisfactory and it was arranged to go into this matter in the presence of the Bishop, Archdeacon Paul and myself as soon as possible, which was yesterday, and I am convinced that the Bishop is only too willing to procure a more suitable teacher if at all possible to do so. Enclosed herewith please find list of supplies required for the John Smith Indian Day School #610, as submitted to this office by the teacher, Miss W. Moore.

Enclosed also please find a letter addressed to the writer over signature of Miss Moore the contents thereof is self explanatory with the following exceptions:

Item 2. Janitor services.

Personally I see no reason why this work cannot be done by the older pupils free of charge to our Branch. Coal burning heating equipment has been installed in both classrooms with this type of equipment tending furnaces does not require any great amount of heavy work in comparison with tending wood burning heating equipment. I will follow the matter closely and if I find that janitor services are necessary a recommendation will be forwarded at a later date.

Item 3. Manual Training.

I am in agreement with Miss Moore in regards to training in wood work. We are fortunate in having one of the members of the John Smith Band who is an experienced and very competent carpenter and wood worker and his services could be made available for say one half day each week during the cold weather months. I estimate this additional training would entail an expenditure of approximately $20.00 per month, plus materials and tools in the amount of $75.00

Item 4. Re application of Mrs Lamb.

We do not appear to have application forms on hand at this office and a supply of application forms are requested.
I might add that I visited the John Smith Indian Day School on September 20th and found both classrooms in operation with a total attendance of 44 children in the school rooms.

The teachers appear to be quite capable and a spirit of enthusiasm was noted throughout by teachers and pupils.

The supplies listed on the enclosure are required as soon as possible.

Regina, November 24th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Miss Wilna Moore, Indian day school teacher at the John Smith's Reserve, of the Duck Lake Agency, has been in communication with Mrs. Flora L. Ross, day school teacher at the Thunderchild Reserve, of the Battleford Agency, regarding instruction in weaving, and is anxious that Mrs. Ross visit the John Smith's Reserve to assist in starting weaving at that school.

As the Department is aware, Mrs. Ross is well qualified to instruct in this work, and her knowledge has been passed on to other day school teachers from time to time, to the benefit of all concerned. I would therefore ask authority to send Mrs. Ross to the John Smith's Day School for the purpose. She would be away from the Thunderchild Day School for a week, but her son, George Ross, who is teaching the second classroom at the Thunderchild Day School, could supervise both rooms for that period without much difficulty.

The cost to the Department will be railway fare from Turtleford to Prince Albert, via North Battleford, and meals and hotel accommodation while passing through North Battleford and Prince Albert. The total cost will not exceed $50.00, and I believe that it will be money well spent.

If this meets with the approval of the Department, arrangements will have to be made with Mrs. Ross and Miss Moore as to the date.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

I regret to state that it appears necessary that I must forward my school returns for the last quarter direct, which are enclosed herewith, and for which I beg to make the following explanation.

It will be noticed that the return of school material has not been filled in, which I am unable to complete as I have not yet received my copy from the Duck Lake office of the September quarter.

Some time in November last I informed the Agent of this, and he stated that if I had not received the third copy back, he could send the office copy for me to make another from that. But he did not do so.

On Tuesday Dec.30 when the Agent was here I asked again for the September quarter, and since then I have received three mails on Jan. 3,6 & to day,16, covering two weeks, and still no September school return. If I send the present returns to Duck Lake they will most likely come back to be completed which means a delay of another two weeks, which I can ill afford.

I would thank the Department for a cheque as soon as possible, and would ask that this not be delayed until the returns are finally completed. I have lately had to pay out upwmd of $109. for beef supplies, as the Indians here simply refuse either to sell or work for the Department unless paid without delay, and to get over this I have to pay out of my own pocket & then take the Indians cheque.

I hate to complain about Mr Agent Schmidt but really sometimes it gets impossible. Thoses September school returns should have been here long ago.

Yours truly,

The Secretary.

Dear Sir,

I have to thank you for your letter No 117684/3, dated April 23, regarding contribution for the Canadian Patriotic Fund from my quarterly salary.

In reply I would like to observe that I notice that this amount is at the rate of $1.00 per month for six months, and also that you have already deducted $1.00 per month from my monthly Overseers cheques; I have before me at present an Overseer cheque No 7028 for $15.75 March salary, and they have been $15.65 for some months past, and it would appear as if you have already overpaid to the Canadian Patriotic Fund the sum of $3.00.

However I have no objection to the overpayment of this amount, but would remark that the officials at the Headquarters of the various funds might be reminded that all these funds are well represented by local organizations which are not at all backward in bringing them to the notice of the outside services.

I have no wish to appear mean in these matters, but with the high cost of living in England at present, I have to send large part of my salary cheque home, and while wishing to support Canadian Funds, it is not always possible to do so to the extent that one would like.

Yours truly,

The Secretary.
Ottawa, May 1, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo in further reference to the deductions on account of the Canadian Patriotic Fund made from your salary as teacher of the John Smith's Day School and as overseer.

In reply I beg to say that deductions have been made for six months from your salary as teacher and overseer in error. This occurred through payments for each of these services being made in different branches of the Department and the deduction on account of the Patriotic Fund was inadvertently noted for payment in each branch. The Department is sending you a cheque for $3.00 on account of the deduction made from your salary as teacher for the March quarter, last, but is unable to refund you the $3.00 for the December quarter, as this amount has been forwarded to the Treasurer of the Canadian Patriotic Fund. There is, therefore, a total amount over deducted in error of $3.00 from your salary as teacher and overseer and it is hoped that you will consent to this amount remaining in the funds of the Patriotic Society, for which you have received due credit.

Your obedient servant,

P. H. Gentleman, Esq.,
Teacher,
John Smith's Day School,
Puckahn, Sask.

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir:

Sir:

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your #109-5-5 dated the 13th instant re my voucher #8601 for $1.00 covering the cost of ice supplied John Smith's School and residence.

I note that there was no letter of explanation sent with the voucher and I very much regret this omission on my part.

The well at the Teachers residence went dry and Rev. Mr Waite the Teacher informed me, I told him to have it cleaned out by an Indian and meanwhile if out of water to get some ice bought from the river, which was done.

On February 20th when on the reserve Rev Mr Waite informed me the well had been cleaned but that the board cribbing being rotten, sand was again caving in; however he said that by melting ice to supplement the limited supply got from the well they were getting along and could wait until a new well was dug this spring. I told him to get more ice if needed and to send the accounts to me. Mr Collins the Clerk prepared the voucher which I signed but forgot to write an explanation.

I beg to ask that this account be paid and that I be authorized to submit voucher in payment for more ice if same is required before a new well is sunk.

I have the honour to be

When visiting this reserve on the 22nd., ultimo I was informed that several wells on the reserve, and in the neighborhood were going dry, and stock were being driven to the river to drink.

I beg to ask that I be authorized to pay $1.00 per load for ice delivered at the school residence.

I am unable to state at present how many loads will be required per month.

On my next visit to the reserve I will look into the matter of deepening the well, a new one sunk this summer which had about three feet of water for several months before it began to lower.

I am writing Rev. Waite telling him to have ice hauled.

I have the honour to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

G.P. Schmidt,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

Reference Page 9, 1937-38 Estimates.

John Smith's Reserve Indian Day School.

I beg to request authority to expend the sum of $350.00 to provide material and labour to do the following work:

Three hundred dollars for labour and material to paint the exterior of the Day School House which has not been painted for over ten years and is badly in need thereof.

An old log lean-to is attached to the log stable and has been used as a shelter for the driving rigs. It is in a state of near collapse, is an eye sore and should be removed before it falls down. This should be replaced by a new drive shed which should not cost more than $50.00 for material and labour.

I recommend that Gilbert Bear, Headman on this Reserve who is experienced and considered very good at this work be employed to do the labour.

It would be appreciated if authority for this work be granted in time that arrangements could be made to have it done while the school is closed for summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,

This leaves the amount of $100.00 available for painting. If the necessary painting cannot be done for this sum, the work will have to remain in abeyance until next year.

Duck Lake, Sask., October 12th, 1937

Dear Sir;

I beg to advise that I consider that the children attending the Day Schools in this Agency are not receiving sufficient nourishment from the cocoa, sugar, biscuits and potatoes served them at noon; especially during the cold Winter months when they have to walk to and from School. I understand that some of these children have little enough to eat before leaving for School and again on their return home. I feel that if a more nourishing meal was provided for them at the School it would not only help to keep these children in better health but it would also assist us to secure a more regular attendance in some of our Day Schools.

I am enclosing herewith a list of supplies which I consider may be required during the coming Winter and Spring. In reference to potatoes being included therein I have to advise that the potato crop in this Agency was very poor this year. It was a total failure on the Moose Woods and Kinistino Reserves. This crop was also very disappointing on the James Smith's Reserve.

In reference to the supplies requested for the School now being built on the Kinistino Reserve I beg to refer to my letter No. 2410-6-31, dated May 26th last, which I advised in part as follows:

"It will be necessary to provide a noon-day meal as well as extra rations in order to secure attendance, as the parents are roamers and make their living by doing odd jobs for the settlers adjoining the Reserve, some hunting, and hay-making. In the Winter months the families who own cattle live at the Winter hay-camp, a distance of 12 miles from the School, as this is the only point at which feed can be procured in sufficient quantities. Arrangements could be made to board their children with families living near the School by supplying them with the following; 12-98s flour, 450 lbs. Beef and 25 lbs. Tea."

I recommend that the supplies mentioned on the attached list be provided and that authority be granted to purchase them as they are required.

Yours very truly,

S.H. Simpson,
Indian Agent.

Dr. T. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

The School House and the School children's Dining Room at the John Smith's Reserve are badly in need of interior decorating.

The paint on the metal ceiling of the school is dropping off, also the kalsomine on the walls of the school and dining room. It will therefore be necessary to have the ceiling and walls cleaned of the old paint and kalsomine before the new can be applied. The cost of labor in this connection will be about $30.00.

I am enclosing form No. 37 in duplicate, requisitioning for material and labor.

I recommend that this work be done and that Indian labor be employed to do it.

Dear Sir:

With reference to our discussion during your recent inspection of this Agency pertaining to the Day School and children's dining room at the John Smiths Reserve being very cold during the winter months, I beg to report as follows:

It is considered that if the ceiling floors of these buildings are insulated with shavings prepared for this purpose it would prevent to a great extent the heat generated in the buildings from escaping. It would also insulate the ceilings against the cold drafts of air that penetrate into the attics of these buildings.

It is estimated that the cost of insulation would be taken care of within two or three years due to the reduction in the quantity of fuel that would be required after the work was completed.

I recommend that this work be done and request authority to have it completed before the school re-opens on October 1st, next.

Form No. 37 listing the cost of materials and labour required are attached hereto.

Yours very truly,

S. H. SIMPSON

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6286, file 610-5, part 5)
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ontario.

I am in receipt of advice from the teacher at the John Smith's Day School, also from the Farming Instructor at this reserve that the well at the school has gone dry.

As it is practically impossible to make a satisfactory job of deepening the well during winter months I recommend that an Indian be employed to haul water to the school for the next four months as from January 4th., 1943 at $2.00 per month.

The matter of deepening the well will be submitted to the Department next March. In the meantime I have requested the Farming Instructor to see that water is supplied at the rate of $2.00 per month and request that the Department concur in this action.

S. H. SIMPSON
INDIAN AGENT.

SHS/H.
Ottawa,

Mr. S.H. Simpson, Indian Agent, Duck Lake, Sask.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I beg to report that the wood burner furnace at the John Smith's Reserve Day School requires the following repairs:

Cement to recement fire box, inside damper to check heat flow from fire box to outside chimney, 2-8" elbows, and 4-8" smoke pipes and 1½ sheets of galvanized iron to repair outside of furnace, total cost of these items is $9.90.

In order to make the required repairs it will be necessary to take the furnace apart. There are no Indians qualified to do this work. I therefore had Mr. Mascho of Mascho and Kernaghan Plumbing and Heating Company of Prince Albert, examine the furnace and advise as to the parts required, the cost thereof, and the cost of labour in this connection. The cost of labour will be $39.00.

Authority is requested to purchase the required repairs and have the necessary work done at a total cost of $48.90.

I beg to enclose herewith voucher no. 281 for $36.50 in favour of Gilbert Bear H.M. for interior decorating of the John Smith's Day School, also for repairs to guard railing around inside entrance to the school basement, and repairs to class room door and book case, damaged by the pupils of the school. The railing around the open wooden porch of the school was also broken off. On examination it was found the sills and wooden foundation had rotted and was unsafe. The old porch was removed and cement steps and platform constructed, and the wooden top of the old porch replaced thereover. The cement that was used was from that left over after completing the Department Farm Buildings on this reserve in 1939. I beg to report that while at the John Smith's Reserve on January 10th I was advised that the well at the Day School there had gone dry. I instructed to have it cleaned out and in the meantime to have ice hauled to the school for drinking and cooking purposes.

The well was cleaned on January 18th which did not result in procuring a supply of water. This well has never given an adequate supply since it was dug in 1935, and water from other sources has since had to be supplied to the school from time to time. I have been advised that it was located away from the well sunk in 1926 which had a good supply of water but was abandoned on account of the cribbing having rotted and caved in.

I recommend that a new well be dug near the site of the 1926 well early in April when the frost is out of the ground. Form No. 37 is attached hereto listing the materials and labour required for this work. The price of the lumber was quoted by the North Star Lumber Company, Prince Albert, who advised that there is no rough lumber available and that the usual 10 per cent discount allowed cannot be given due to recent regulations made by the War Time Prices and Trade Board.

I beg to request authority to expend the sum of $4.00 per month to employ Indian labour to haul ice or water for the Day School and Teacher's residence until other arrangements can be made.

Voucher No. 685, $4.50 in favour of Gilbert Crain is attached hereto for ice supplied to cover requirements for January and part of February, 1944.

S.H. SIMPSON

John Smith's Reserve;

April 19, 1944.

M. Christianson, Esq., General Superintendent of Indian Agencies,
Federal Building, Regina, Sask.

Re: Schools, Repairs Buildings and Works
Page 76691 and 76693 Estimates 1944-45.

I beg to enclose herewith Form No. 37 with extra copy for your office, listing materials and work required in this connection as follows:

**Interior of Teacher's Residence, John Smith's Day School - $128.00**

The floors in the dining room and hallway of this residence is badly worn. It only consists of one ply of lumber. A new floor of one ply of lumber is required to cover the worn parts of the old one and particularly to strengthen it. Experienced Indian labour is available at this reserve to do the necessary work. The other materials listed to finish the flooring and interior cleaning of the house.

**Moose Woods Sioux Day School - Teacher's Residence - $18.00**

Five window blinds are needed to replace the old ones which have worn out, the other materials are needed for cleaning of the home.

**Moose Woods Sioux Day School - School House - $60.00**

The interior of this building is badly in need of interior decorating. Indian labour to do the necessary work is available at the reserve.

**Fort a la Corne North Day School - Teacher Residence - $35.00**

Interior cleaning of this home is needed. The wall paper is required for the dining and sitting rooms.

**Fort a la Corne North Day School - School House - $86.00**

The interior of this building requires re-decorating. Labour is available to do the work.

**Fort a la Corne South Day School - School House - $92.00**

The interior of this building is in need of re-decoration. Indian labour is available for this work.

**Fort a la Corne South Day School - Teacher's Residence - $4.00**

**Kinistino Day School - Teacher's Residence - $32.00**

The materials listed are for interior decorating required in this home.

If there are any funds available for outside repairs to school buildings provision should be made to do all buildings at the Fort a la Corne North School which are very badly in need of re-painting. The buildings at the South School also should be done, but at present are in better condition than those at the other school. Both these items are listed in the estimates.

S.H. SIMPSON
INDIAN AGENT

In the 1944-45 Estimates, Duck Lake Agency, a request was made for interior decorations of the teachers' residences, at John Smith's Reserve, Moose Woods Sioux Reserve, James Smith Reserve, and Kinistino Reserve.

I would recommend that these be approved of and granted. Mr. Simpson, the Agent, states that with respect to the interior decorations at the John Smith Day School the floors in the dining room and hall way are badly worn and in the first place there is only a one-ply lumber. There is sufficient experienced Indian labour on the reserve to do the work.

The Agent also requests that if funds are available outside repairs be made to the Fort A La Corne North Indian Day School. This building is in bad need of re-painting. I also notice that the South School on the same reserve could do with a re-painting but at the present time it is in better shape than the school north of it.

Dear Sir,

You will be able no doubt that I wrote you in reference to Indian Education on a former occasion. I am still of the same opinion and unhesitatingly repeat that the Boarding School System should be extended till it becomes general.

At this Mission we have a small Day School and since the parents have scattered all over the Reserve attendance at school is certainly very poor but taking the distances and the weather into account the attendance is very good.

I have frequently been asked to take in the children as boarders but as you know I have no room, no authority nor funds to do so. A school of from 40 to 50 pupils children of our Church people and Reformed could be easily got together here if we had the premises and the maintenance...

Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA, 5th March, 1901

The Secretary:

With reference to the application of Rev. Owen Owens for a grant to establish a boarding school at St. Andrew's Mission Keys Reserve, Swan River Agency, I beg to say that there are 621 Indians in this agency, 167 of whom are Anglicans, 167 Presbyterians, 34 Roman Catholics and 223 Pagans. The Presbyterians have a boarding school on Cote's Reserve.

It seems that every Protestant denomination, as well as the Roman Catholics engaged in Indian work in the North-West, appears to think that they are entitled to a boarding school on the particular reserve on which they are working, ostensibly for the education of Indian children, but in reality for the support of the mission, and there is no limit to their demands for this class of school.

You will see by the statement I sent you a few days ago, showing the accommodation of the different boarding and industrial schools, that there is no necessity for increasing their number at present. There are vacancies at the Elkhorn Industrial school where the children of Indians belonging to the Church of England could be sent.

The Government has never taken the initiative in establishing boarding schools as yet, and I do not think they should do so in this case.

To The Hon. D. Laird,
Indian Commissioner,
Winnipeg, Man.

Sir,

As teacher of Key's School and Missionary in charge of the S. Andrew Anglican Mission, Key's Reserve, permit me to request your immediate consideration of educational matters on Key's Reserve and Key's Band.

We have as you are aware a Day School here. It has been in continuous work since the year 1885. As far as a Day School can be it has been a success.

When this school was first opened every family on the Reserve were living at a distance of not more than one mile and a half from the school house. Attendance at school in such a case might be expected to be regular, but the average attendance then was not much higher than it is now. I took charge of the school on the first of July 1896 and have been always diligent in persuading parents to keep their children regularly at school with no time better results than an average equal to one half of the number of pupils on the school roll. Of late years the tents have had to scatter all over the Reserve in amount of the increasing quantity of hay required for each man's cattle. So that to-day we have only three families living within two miles of the school. The remainder are located in various directions extending from two and one half to about 5 miles by trail from the school house. Nearly all these families have one or more children close on school age but there are no elderly children to bring them to school from such a distance. Even if they had judging by past experience their attendance would so intermittent as to make permanent progress in their case very small. So small that in a few years after leaving school they will have forgotten nearly everything even the little English that may have been forced upon them.

The whole band are fully alive to the immediate need of a better educational system for their children. The chief and every other head of a family on the Reserve have twice this summer come to me requesting in the most pressing manner that I should call your attention and the attention of the Bishop Qu'Appelle to their urgent need of a boarding school for their children. They promised that twenty-five pupils would be forthcoming for a boarding school at once on its opening. The chief and headmen also desired me to tell you and the Bishop that they have a promise from the portion of the band that have not yet settled here; but who are now and always have been leading a wandering life, hunting and fishing; that they will furnish many pupils for a boarding school if one is opened here on their own reserve.

My own opinion is that if half of the promises are fulfilled, accommodation for thirty-five at least will be acquired within twelve months of the date of opening the school. It is perfectly useless to speak to them of sending their children away to distant schools as not only most of those that did go only came back to die, but also the education received has in most cases been of a character little suited to the needs of their future mode of life. I can bear witness to the undoubted fact that the pupils of the Boarding Schools in this and the Touchwood Hills Agencies have given satisfaction almost all whereas in the same Agencies the pupils of distant schools have not been a success. In fact some of them are decidedly detrimental in their influence on their less favoured friends. It is so here that any Missionary Teacher

Teacher or Government Officer who would advocate sending more children to distant schools would forfeit all of what influence for good he might otherwise possess and justly so as all persons qualified to speak could tell you.

I have already told you the conditions of attendance at the Day School here. I may be allowed to state farther that the most important part of an Indian child's education—the implanting of permanent habits of regularity and industry—is impossible in a day school.

The Deputy Superintendent General:-

The Indian Commissioner under date the 17th instant encloses a copy of a letter from the Rev. Owen Owens, Church of England Missionary on the Key's Reserve, urging upon the Department the advisability of establishing a boarding school there.

The total population of the Pelly Agency is 473. The last census gives the membership of the Church of England as only 47; the remainder being made up of 178 Presbyterians, 75 Roman Catholics, and 153 Pagans. There are two boarding schools already in operation there - the Crowstand conducted by the Presbyterians, which has an enrolment of 45 with an average attendance of 41. The Roman Catholics have a boarding school at Kisickonse which is not yet in receipt of the Government grant, but will be recognized when the St. Boniface deal is consummated. No returns are received from this school but I understand that they have an enrolment of about 15. The two Church of England day schools in the Agency, one on the Key's Reserve with an enrolment of 19, and the other at Shoal River with 25 on the roll. There are only about 120 children of school age in the Agency, and the present school enrolment accounts for about 92 of this number.

Mr. Owen's scheme would involve an immediate outlay of about $5,000.00 for buildings, $1,800.00 for the maintenance of 25 pupils and an additional $1,000.00 for equipment, and

I do
I do not think the Department could look to the Church of England for any substantial assistance either for buildings or maintenance as they have no money to spend. Mr. Owens has evidently taken his cue from the Minister's speech on the School Estimates in which he expressed himself in favor of the boarding school as affording the best means of educating and civilizing the Indian. I do not think the children of this Agency would suffer if action is delayed. The Church of England have a General Secretary for Indian Mission work and applications such as this should, I think, come through that officer, and the Department would then be in a position to find out how far the Missionary Society is able and willing to contribute to such work.

Dear sir,

I am instructed by my Vicar, the Rev. Walter Western of Pelly, to lay the following matter before you.

One Sunday in every four he visits the Mission Church here to give the Indians a Celebration of the Holy Eucharist and on that Sunday I take his duty at White Beech, on Thunder Hill, at least thirty-two miles from here. I have done this so far, but it is very tiring both for me and my pony. What we wished to ask is your permission to close the school on that one Monday a month and teach on the following Saturday instead. The attendance and progress of the children since your visit of inspection has been very satisfactory. The children begin to understand English and I have gone slowing with them and have the satisfaction of knowing that what they can read they understand.

I wish I could say the same of the school grounds. The stable is as yet unfinished and I had to stable my horse a half mile from school all winter and walk through the snow. I am at present trying to get the land behind the school ploughed for a garden. I think however I shall be successful in this. The privies for which lumber was granted are not up. As I had to use the school while making the interest payments the teacher had to dismiss the children for that afternoon. I believe there were seven children present. Dear Mr. Scott:

I am herewith enclosing Inspector Christianson's report on the schools in the Belly Agency.

The work in the little Anglican school on the Key reserve seems to be progressing satisfactorily.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.
A new building of the improved type has been erected since my last visit, the old building having been destroyed by fire this spring.

There are 8 pupils registered and the grades range from 1 to 6. These children appear well along in their grades and I think Mr. Kerley, the teacher, is doing good work. In addition to the classroom work, each summer the children put in large gardens, the work of which Mr. Kerley supervises. This year the vegetables are excellent and there will be abundance of potatoes, carrots, beets and onions with which to supply the noon-day meal, which meal is prepared by Mrs. Kerley.

The verandah on the teacher's residence has been screened during the summer and this has made a great improvement as it was practically useless before.

The house

ST. ANDREW'S DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The house is in good repair and the upkeep in connection with the school should not amount to much for some time.
KEY DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on two occasions, but was not there when the children were in class. I saw the children, however, and they appeared to be quite clean, well clothed, and had a happy appearance. There are 10 pupils enrolled, 7 boys and 3 girls. Two of these, I believe, are only attending temporarily pending their return to the boarding school. The School Inspector had visited them shortly before my arrival, and I understand was quite pleased with the progress they are making in their studies.

I found both the teacher's cottage and the schoolroom in a good state of repair. There is a large vegetable garden, in which the children are given individual plots to care for. The garden has been well cared for, and has produced a fine crop, principally potatoes.
KEY DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Potatoes, carrots, onions, and turnips. I have seldom seen vegetables of a finer quality. The children are permitted to take the produce from their individual plots, to their homes as the teacher has a sufficiently large garden to provide the requirements for the mid-day meal, which is provided at this school.

Mr. W. J. D. Kerley, the teacher, appears to be well qualified. He has a second class teacher's certificate.

The foregoing report is respectfully submitted.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 17th instant, No.117-4-1, I have to say that when the Farming Instructor at the Key's Reserve resigned as from 1st May the work of the Indians in connection with seeding had just commenced, and as I am without a clerk at the Agency I was unable to devote much of my time to the farming at that point.

Dr. Robertson authorized me to arrange for Mrs. Kerley to temporarily continue with the classroom work at the Key's Day School in order to allow Mr. Kerley some freedom to get about the Reserve and encourage and assist the Indians to get their crop in in time.

Mrs. Kerley is thirty-five years of age. She is not qualified to teach school in this province, but informs me that she taught a little over a year as supplementary teacher for primary work in a school in London, England. This is the only experience she has had, but as Mr. Kerley is with her off and on during the day the classroom work is going on practically the same as before.

They have two children, a boy of eight and a half years and a girl of six and a half years, and so far as I am aware Mrs. Kerley is not wishing to be appointed as teacher at the school and is only assisting us temporarily until some arrangement can be made. If your inquiry is made with a view to considering appointing Mrs. Kerley as teacher, I would respectfully suggest that no further consideration be given to the matter. However, she could certainly continue to teach for the remainder of this term without any material damage being done to the welfare of the pupils of the school.
Mr. Kerley would like to be appointed permanently as farming instructor or clerk at this Agency, preferably as clerk, both of which positions are now vacant, and he is capable of filling either position to the satisfaction of all concerned, but in either case Mrs. Kerley would not want to continue teaching the Day School.

Dear Sirs:-

re J.Jolley, School Teacher on Keys Indian Reserve south of Norquay Sask. and R.Chaloner (Garage Proprietor) of Norquay Sask.

I have been requested by R.Chaloner, Garage Proprietor here to write with regard to an account he has outstanding against Mr Jolley, Teacher at the Indian School on the Keys Reserve south of Town.

This account dates back to February 5th 1938, and runs along to December 6th 1938, and amongst other things covers the purchase of the items for automobiles such as tubes, repair to tire work, and also purchase of a radio set, and charging of batteries presumably for such radio. A total of $26.00 credit on the account leaves today owing the sum of $57.41. Last payment on account was $10.00 on December 6th 1938.

I have written to Jolley in a decent way for Mr. Chaloner asking for settlement of the account, and Chaloner was willing to clear the account by partial payments, but, Jolley, ignores the letter I have written him, has ignored the bills and statements of accounts Chaloner has sent him, and now of course does not come near Chaloner's established place of business, and the matter irks Mr. Chaloner.

Hence this letter, appealing to you, to arrange to have Mr Jolley make settlement of this account either direct with my client, or by means of payments out of his salary from the Department. It is ridiculous that a man of Mr Jolley's standing should act thusly with a fair and decent minded business man like Chaloner and I think the case warrants your consideration.

I will be obliged if you would write to either myself or Mr Chaloner at once advising what assistance you will give. Thanking you.

Yours truly,

THOMAS W. SMITH

Right Reverend Sir:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of the 14th instant, in which you submit, for departmental approval, the nomination of Reverend James Marsden Buck for the position of teacher of the Key Indian Day School, Norquay P. O., Sask.

It is noted that Mr. Buck has secured Grade XII standing in the province of Saskatchewan, in addition to his theological training. It does not appear, however, that he has at any time taken the regular normal school course for teachers in the province of Saskatchewan.

I may state that about two years ago Dr. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Agencies for Saskatchewan, complained rather vigorously to the Department that a number of the teachers nominated by the Churches were wholly unsuitable for work on Indian reserves. Dr. Robertson at that time had in mind teachers with full academic and professional standing and with some training or experience in agricultural methods. The matter was very fully discussed at that time and Bishop Burd, during one of his visits to the East, went into the problem very fully with the officials here and, if I remember correctly, with the Minister. It was finally decided by Bishop Burd that only teachers with full professional and academic standing would be nominated by him for positions at Indian day schools. Dr. Robertson was finally persuaded

that -

Right Reverend E. H. Knowles, LL.B., D.D.,
Bishop of Qu'Appelle,
Bishop's Court,
Regina, Sask.
that this was all we could possibly expect from the church authorities. If we now accept for the position at the Key School a teacher lacking professional qualifications, I am afraid that such an appointment may create a certain amount of dissatisfaction in other sections of Saskatchewan, particularly in the northern districts. It is just possible that there may be a scarcity of teachers in the immediate future and that we may have to appoint teachers lacking professional qualifications. I do feel, however, in the meantime, that a fully qualified teacher should be nominated for the Key School or that we should have, in writing, a statement intimating that it has not been found possible to secure a fully qualified teacher at this particular time.

I regret to trouble Your Lordship with this matter, but you will, I feel sure, readily appreciate the position in which I find myself.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.
