My dear Mr. Hoey,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 19th inst. in regard to the appointment of the Rev. J.M. Buck of Togo, Sask., to the Indian School on the Key Indian Reserve. I have noted carefully what you say with regard to the person to be appointed to this work having professional qualifications, i.e. a Normal School training. This point was carefully considered by us before we recommended Mr. Buck for the position as at present we have not a clergyman in Orders in this Diocese who has a Normal School Certificate and is available for this work.

While we have every regard for the desire of the Department to always have professional teachers in our Indian Schools yet may I suggest to you that there are other qualifications which might easily far exceed the advantage of Normal School training so far as the particular work on Key Indian Reserve is concerned. The school is not a large one and the pupils are not nearly as far advanced as they are in some other Indian Day Schools. Again, important as the teaching experience is, yet in our purview it is even more important on this particular Reserve that the teacher and his wife would be people who in their social life with the Indians and the help that they could give them in their daily life and work is a most important factor. In this we have no doubt in assuring you that the Rev. J.M. Buck and his wife are highly qualified and we do not think for a moment that the lack of a professional certificate will in any way hinder the good work that it is possible for this man and wife to do for your Indian people on this Reserve.
Mr. R.A. Hoey,

If I could secure a clergyman who is a qualified teacher I would not hesitate in doing so but, as before stated, we have not one amongst our clergy at the moment who could satisfy this requirement. May I therefore ask that under these circumstances you would reconsider the appointment of Mr. Buck.

I am,
Yours very truly,

Report on the Key Indian Day School

I wish to inform you that while at the Pelly Agency, Kamsack, last week, I visited the above mentioned school.

There were 14 children present at the school at the time of my visit.

I spent about a couple of hours going over the school and teacher's residence and this is the first time I have visited the school since the present teacher, the Reverend Marsden Buck, took charge. There is a good school garden there this year.

Mr. and Mrs. Buck are a young couple both raised on the farm, and they have two small children. They both seem to be nice young people but as a teacher I was not impressed with this man. As far as I could make out he is not a disciplinarian and I noticed discipline seemed to be lacking altogether. Therefore I would say that the work is taught in a more or less haphazard way. However, class was not on at the time I was present and I am only surmising this but I do not think I am very far wrong. In discussing Mr. Buck with our Agent I came to the conclusion that a little talking to might do some good and I hope to have an opportunity for a real heart to heart talk with him before the school opens in the Fall as I expect to be down in that part of the country again some time during the summer.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
MC/ed General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Re: Ethel BRASS (Juvenile) and Evelyn CALDWELL (T.I.'s)
B.S. & Theft (450-368) from School Storehouse,

[DELLY DETACHMENT CASE]

19-7-42

On this date, the Rev. J.M. BUCK, Anglican Minister and Indian school teacher, employed at the Indian School on the Keys Indian Reserve, called at this detachment and complained that during the first week in July this year, some persons had unlawfully entered the storehouse in his school by means of a skeleton key and had stolen therefrom four dresses, two coats and various other articles of clothing. Mr. Buck went on to say that the clothing stolen was part of a bale of used clothes sent to the Reserve by the Anglican Church in Ontario for distribution amongst the needy Indians. It was learned that at the time of the offence, Complainant and his wife were away on vacation. Mr. BUCK stated that actually the clothes stolen were not of a very great value but previous petty thefts had been committed in and about the school premises and he felt that the matter should be investigated. As good a description as possible was obtained from Complainant but due to the fact that he and his wife had only casually checked over the bale, complete description was not available.

Mr. BUCK gave good reasons for believing that two Indian girls - the captionally noted - were responsible for the offence, but he stated that at the moment they were both away to the Yorkton Fair and he understood that from there they were going to the Regina Fair and that therefore it would be useless to make a patrol to the Reserve. He stated that he would advise us when the girls were at home on the Reserve.

Recently, information was received that the two suspects had returned to the Reserve, therefore, on the p.m. of the 7th Inst., whilst in Porcupine on other duties, patrol was extended per /car Code # 8127 to the Keys Indian Reserve for the purpose of investigating this complaint. On arrival, Rev. BUCK and his wife interviewed and further information obtained. It was learned that on a recent date, Evelyn CALDWELL had called on Mrs. BUCK and handed her a brown flannel dress, complete with belo which they positively identified as being one of the dresses stolen herein. Evelyn was questioned by Mrs. BUCK and she stated that Ethel BRASS had given her the dress and that she did not know where she (Ethel) got it but she had since heard that it was stole.

Complainant also went on to state that he had heard that Mr. KANE, resident near the school had found some clothes hidden in the bush near his house. Evelyn CALDWELL had been visiting at the KANE house during the week that this offence was committed.

5. Patrol extended to the house of William Keys. He was away from home but his wife stated that the information obtained was correct. She produced a rose and pink shade girl's light coat and a man's brown suit coat, both garments had been chewed by gobers and were now of little or no value. The girl's light coat was positively identified by Mr. Buck as being one of those taken from the sale. I took possession of these articles for further investigation.

6. Patrol extended about the Reserve in an effort to locate these two girls for interrogation. Ethel BRASS had gone to Norway with her mother and Evelyn CALDWELL was berry picking, however, after considerable searching, the Caldwell girl was located and in due course the following statement was obtained:

RESIDES: About the beginning of July 1942, Ethel BRASS and I went to the school on the Keys Indian Reserve, it was after dark. Ethel went there to get some blankets which she had left in the school. I knew that Mr. & Mrs. Buck were away. The school is never locked. Ethel went into the school and I stayed on the road allowance. After a short while she came back carrying the blankets; at that time I did not know that she had anything else but the blankets. The next day I found out that she had some dresses etc., wrapped up inside the blankets. I did not find this out until the following evening. She gave me a brown flowered dress, a greyish coat, a blue dress and a little grey skirt. At the time she gave me these clothes I did not know she had stolen them. I thought it was her own as she has lots of clothes. When I found out that these things were stolen, I took the brown flowered dress back to Mrs. Buck, I traded the grey coat with Mrs. Jim Crane for a jacket, I still have the blue dress and the grey skirt at home. I don't know how Ethel got into the storeroom at the school.

Sgd. Evelyn Caldwell.

7. Evelyn Caldwell is a member of the Cote band of Indians but is visiting on the Keys Reserve. She does not enjoy a very good reputation, her mother was murdered about 5 years ago by Louis Severight on the Cote Reserve. She is 16 years of age, she will be 17 years next Febry. 22nd, 1943. I felt that she was not telling the whole truth but she stoutly maintained that she was not a party to this offence.

8. The blue dress and the grey skirt were produced and handed over. An effort was made to locate Mrs. Jim Crane in order that we could question her regarding the grey coat but the whole Crane family were away. From other Indians it was learned however that she has the grey coat.

9. My enquiries led me to interview Mrs. Russell BRASS as it was indicated that she had purchased a dress from Ethel BRASS. The following statement was obtained—about a month ago, Ethel BRASS sold me a white dress with green leaves and dots on it. I paid her $3.50 for it. She said she got the dress from Mrs. Bryant, the Agent's wife at Cote Indian Res. I heard some time after I bought the dress that it had been stolen from the school. I never spoke to Ethel about where she got it from. (con. on page 3)

WHICH WERE scattered about the Reserve and hand them over to Mr. HICK.

14. There is no doubt but that both of these girls are guilty of the offence indicated and that they would plead "Guilty" should a charge be laid. In spite of the fact that Ethel BRASS appeared to be telling the most complete story, she enjoys a more unsavoury reputation than the girl Evelyn. It is considered that she was the one that thought of and engineered the affair. Mr. HICK reports that she is a very poor pupil and does not attend school regularly. Her father, Solomon BRASS is in the Army, stationed at Saskatoon, her mother is considered a very loose woman and the home atmosphere is far from good. It is suggested that this girl's morals are not of the best, in fact there seems to be a suspicion that she is suffering from venereal disease, contracted from some source whilst she was attending the fairs held at Yorkton Regina & Saskatoon. She denied that she had such disease although admitted that she had recently received a letter from the Chief of Police in Saskatoon, telling her that she was apparently suffering from gonorrhea and advising her to take proper treatment. He stated that she did not know from whom the Chief had obtained this information.

15. Indian Agent BRYANT of Cote I.E. has been contacted in this regard. He stated that he would advise Dr. J.I. WALLACE of Lumsden, Indian Doctor of this possibility and that appropriate steps would be taken to have the girl examined.

16. In view of the fact that a Juvenile is involved herein no Information and Complaint has been laid by the Complainant, although he feels that this girl should be prosecuted. Mr. HICK is rather inclined to the belief that a spell in the Reform School would be a good thing for this girl; however, he states that he will be content to abide by the wishes of the Police or the Bureau of Child Protection. In view of the fact that Evelyn CALDWELL is just past the Juvenile age, he does not feel it would be just right to prosecute Evelyn and not Ethel, particularly when it is considered that Ethel has a more questionable reputation than Evelyn.

17. Personally I feel that this investigation in itself will have a good effect on these girls; however, the Rev. HICK who is personally acquainted with these girls, is rather inclined to favour a prosecution, particularly against the Juvenile, he considers that she is a loose, bad girl and there does appear to be good reasons for his opinion. In view of the facts outlined, it is respectfully requested that the matter be referred to the proper Departments for an expression of their wishes.

18. It might be stated that it is hard to estimate the value of the clothing stolen, however, Complainant places it in the neighbourhood of $5-10. F.246 attached covering the articles recovered and held.

I have to report that I visited the Key's Indian Day School of the Pelly Agency on the 12th instant in company with Mr. J.L. Bryant, the Indian Agent.

I do not consider Mr. Browne a satisfactory teacher. The discipline in the classroom was about the worst I have ever seen. The children were wandering about the room at will, talking to each other, interrupting each other at their work, interrupting the teacher when he was trying to give lessons to others, and there was a steady procession of children to and from the room.

More than half of the children were sitting in the classroom with their overshoes on their feet, and their face and hands were not clean, their wearing apparel generally untidy and badly chosen. There were twenty-five names on the roll with eighteen present on that day, but the continuous wandering in and out of the room by the children made it difficult for me to actually check the number of children who were present.

As to the results of Mr. Browne's teaching, I have nothing favourable to report. I do not believe Mr. Browne knows whether he is accomplishing anything or not. He was endeavouring to teach reading to one class and there was such a noise going on that I could not tell whether the children were reading properly or not.

Mr. Browne's personal appearance was certainly no example to the untidy and badly clothed children. He was badly in need of a shave, and was wearing a sweater, a pair of old trousers, and a pair of moccasins. The trousers are apparently the ones he has been wearing when he milks the cow and had an accumulation of milk stains of long standing.

The habits of personal cleanliness and tidiness of Indian children are bad enough even when the best possible example is set by the teacher; and this is my reason for criticising Mr. Browne's personal appearance.

AGENT'S REPORT FOR THE QUARTER ENDING DECEMBER 31st 1945.

XX XX XX

Education

Indian education is a subject that has, I am sure given our department and all who are really interested in the Indians, very serious thought; the problems are many and it would appear that there is still room for some improvement in our present set up. Very few of the day schools have qualified teachers and I think these should be employed by the department and not by any church organization if we are going to get suitable men and women for this very important work. A day school teacher could be employed for the full 12 months, and they should devote considerable in organizing sports and healthy recreation for the young people.

We have one residential school and two day schools at this agency, but have several pupils from all reserves attending residential schools at other points in Saskatchewan and Manitoba. In a residential school good management and an efficient teaching staff are a prime necessity and in St Philips school here, we fortunately have a good teaching staff and a school that is exceptionally well managed. Apart from academic subjects the pupils are taught cooking, sewing, general housework, manual training, field work, care of livestock, and poultry etc. This school is filled to capacity at present and there are several pupils at home at present that should be in school if accommodation was available. There should be provision made for at least another 40 pupils and this may not be sufficient in another ten years. We would also like to see pupils that are anxious to make something of themselves, given the opportunity of staying on in school after they are 16 years old, in fact I think it would be a great help to many of the girls if they were kept in Boarding school at least another year longer.

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd inst. advising me that you are instructing Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander to notify the Rev. W.F. Browne, teacher of the Key Indian Day School that his services are not required after the end of June.

I have recently had an interview with the Rev. W.F. Browne who came to Regina for a special medical examination on a heart condition from which he is suffering and which is serious.

I have his written statements of the events which led to his being in a condition to which Mr. Ostrander has good cause to report to you adversely about him, as follows: "On the evening before Mr. Ostrander's visit, I had been called out at 11:00 P.M. to bring the doctor out from Norquay (13½ miles) to a sick baby, and to a woman in childbirth. The roads were bad; so bad that in bringing the doctor out the car skidded on the icy road, and landed in the ditch. However, we got out again and resumed our journey. After taking the doctor to the two sick persons, it was 5:30 A.M. when I reached home. Rising that morning at 7:00 A.M. I was required about 8:30 A.M. to drive the doctor back to Norquay, he having completed his duties. It was quite late when I got home again that morning. This disruption accounts for my not having shaved, nor having taken time to change into my regular school clothes. So then, Mr. Ostrander saw me under very exceptional conditions. The only lack of discipline lay in the fact that one of the beginners class interrupted to ask some questions of her teacher. It was reading lesson time, and some of the younger children, just the same as in other schools, had not completely mastered the art of silent reading, but mumbled or whispered as they read to themselves. Both Mr. Bryant (the Indian Agent) and the school inspectors would testify to the quiet and good order in the school on the occasions of their visits, and which is the general condition."
Mr. Browne is perfectly willing to resign his position, but feels this explanation should be made known to you.

His deep interest in the Indian Work is such that he pleaded with me that he might remain at the school until it is possible for us to provide a successor, fearing, as we do, the consequences upon the Indians on the Reserve if there should be a long interregnum before another teacher can be obtained.

I have taken up this matter with the Chairman of our Indian Committee (The Rev. F.E.R. Badham, Secretary of Synod, Synod Office, Regina,) and the members of the Committee, and we are now advertising and making every effort to obtain the services of another teacher. We have already advertised for several weeks, but so far without success. We shall continue these efforts until a teacher can be obtained. It is our hope that we may be successful before the end of June, and we shall keep you advised in the matter.

I am, Sir,
Yours very faithfully,

What is your policy regarding the teachers salaries? Are the teachers graded and paid according to their qualifications? We are of the opinion that provided the teachers have similar qualifications, there should be no difference in the salary paid to those teaching in Indian Day Schools.

You will be pleased to know that at long last we are meeting with some response in our appeal for a teacher on the Key Reserve. Since the vacancy occurred, we have been advertising in the church and secular press, only to be disappointed with the applications made. Three ladies - two of them elderly enquired about the position, but they were not very interested. The prospect of living alone, so far removed from others, and without telephone communication, did not appeal to them. Two laymen, both retired school principals are interested in the position, both should be acceptable to the Department of Indian Affairs, but as yet they have not submitted their applications.

As you know there is a scarcity of teachers in our Province. Those who apply to teach in Indian Schools do so because they are especially suitable and qualified for the work and like the Indians, or because they cannot be a success as a teacher in the "white" schools. On the other hand, there are those well-intentioned and missionary-minded ones
who wish to undertake this work. These people at the present time, appear to be definitely in the minority.

I suggest that there are a number of essentials, if we are to get teachers for our Indian Day Schools:

1. They should have a knowledge and liking for the people, and the children they are going to work with.
2. They should receive a salary at least equal to what is paid by the Province of Saskatchewan, where the minimum salary is $1200.00.
3. There should be continuity of pension rights. We have had applicants terminate an interview on being informed that the time given to teaching in Indian Schools would be considered as lost time, so far as their superannuation is concerned.
4. Warm and comfortable homes for the teachers. In this connection a well built and roomy basement is a necessity, if the teacher is to be able to keep vegetables required, not only for their own use but for the noon-day meals they prepare for the school children. Good drinking water is also of great importance.
5. A good road from the teacherage to the nearest highway or municipal road, also telephone communication to the "out-side". A teacher may require the services or advice of a Doctor for herself or himself and family and for the Indians amongst whom they live.

Regarding the present situation at Keys may we have your permission to engage a person whom we feel is able to teach the children but who is not a certified teacher, and may we offer a salary similar to that at present being paid to Mr. R. Hick of the Day Star School. We are, of course, most anxious to obtain well-qualified and suitable teachers for our Indian Day Schools, but it may be expedient that we should get the next best, when they are not available.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 31st re the Rev. Dr. G.H. Mansbridge and the Keys Indian School.

I am wondering why Dr. and Mrs. Mansbridge were both teaching at the same time in the class room. Such a situation coupled with the fact that you were present making an inspection, would I am sure, be sup-setting to Dr. Mansbridge, and you would not see him at his best in the class room. Knowing the size of the class room it would seem to me to be an almost impossible task for two people to be teaching at the same time. No doubt Mrs. Mansbridge was there for the purpose of helping her husband, and I am glad to know that you recognize and appreciate her ability as a teacher.

From the stand point of education, I venture to say that there are few people in this Province who have the qualifications that Dr. Mansbridge has, but I recognize the fact that he had no experience as a teacher in a public school before going to Key Reserve. Do you not think that Dr. Mansbridge might acquire ability to teach, especially in view of the fact that he has Mrs. Mansbridge to help him?

I note that you emphasize the fact that Dr. Mansbridge has never attended Normal School, and while I realize that this is a requirement before a Teacher's Certificate can be issued, I know from experience that some who have attended Normal School and who have been granted a Certificate, have shown little ability to teach.

I wish you to know that we feel that the best is not too good for our Indian children, and that we appreciate your efforts to assist us in this direction. At the same time we are anxious that Dr. Mansbridge should be given a fair chance to prove his ability as a teacher. I realize that you are a very busy man, and that your work covers a large territory, but I am wondering if it would not be possible for you to make a further inspection of the Key School perhaps near the end of this month, or at a time when Dr. Mansbridge will have had sufficient time to prove whether or not he has the ability to teach the children.

Yours truly,

Extracts from Report of Mr. J. P. Gorehynski, Superintendent of Schools, Kansas, Saskatchewan, following his inspection of the Key Indian Day School, March 15, 1948.

Dr. Mansbridge has taken charge of Key Indian Day School in May, 1947. He has excellent academic standing but no teaching experience. After graduating with Ph.D. in London, he was employed as research technician in biology and foods. He specialized in biology.

Although Dr. Mansbridge is not acquainted with teaching techniques and newer methods in the primary grades, his work in the classroom is satisfactory. His kindly manner and attitude secure splendid classroom co-operation.

In reading, the selections studied were well analyzed, explained and discussed. The pupils read well but are somewhat deficient in comprehension. The writing and spelling as well as number work are well taught.

The classroom is too overcrowded. An additional building, with separate cloakrooms, cupboards, bookcases and washing facilities is strongly recommended. The old building could be converted into a kitchen, dining room and recreation hall. At present, noon lunch is served in crowded classrooms. An allowance of $60.00 per annum for noon meal is insufficient. It should be doubled, since at least 12 beginners are to start school this spring.

Sport equipment and facilities are inadequate. At least one football should be provided for winter months. Swings, tester-totters would be very helpful for playground activities.

Health rules and general cleanliness should receive more emphasis.

Considering the equipment available and the lack of classroom materials, Dr. Mansbridge is doing good work in this school.

I would kindly refer you to my letter of June 4th, 1947. In view of the complaints we received it is indeed gratifying to know that School Inspector Gorchynski on March 15th reported that "Considering the equipment available and the lack of classroom materials, Dr. Mansbridge is doing good work in this school." I feel, Sir, that it is to your Department that we must look for guidance in respect to the teachers we have in our Indian Day Schools and that we should expect reports on their teaching ability from a qualified school inspector rather than the Superintendent of Indian Agencies. I realize of course, that we must look to the latter on the general conduct etc. of our teachers. We have noted the suggestions made by the school inspector for the improvement of this school and trust that those things which are the concern and responsibility of the Department of Indian Affairs will be attended to as soon as possible.

Ottawa, May 25, 1919.

Sir,

On the 17th instant the Department mailed you by registered letter cheque No. 2645 for $125.00 salary as teacher of the Keyw Indian Day School for the December quarter. Ottawa, February 6, 1919.

Sir,

On the 17th of January last, the Department mailed, by registered letter to A. J. Lawes, Fort Pelly, Sask., a cheque No. 2645 for $125.00, being the salary of the teacher of the Keys Indian Day School for the December quarter.

This cheque was sent in error to Mr. Lawes and should have been drawn and sent to B. H. L. Dance, who taught during that quarter. A night lettergram was sent Mr. Lawes on the 25th ultimo in which he was asked to return the cheque and he was also written to on the same date confirming the lettergram. No reply has been received up to the present time and I have to request that you will be good enough to make enquiry regarding this matter.

Mr. Lawes should either return the cheque or refund the amount, or it will be satisfactory if he endorses the cheque and hands it over to Mr. Dance. You will be good enough to inform the Department as soon as possible regarding this matter.

Your obedient servant

J. H. Wallis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack,
Sask.

Sir,

In reply to Department's letter No 117074-3 of the 6th inst re mis-direction of salary cheque for teacher of Key Day School for December quarter I beg to inform you that I have instructed the Postmaster at Fort Pelly to forward the registered letter to Mr A.J.Lawes at St Luke's Mission,Punnichy, at which place I understand Mr Lawes is located.

I have also written Mr Lawes requesting him to endorse the cheque and return same to Mr Dance at Fort Pelly, and I have notified Mr Dance of action taken. I trust this meets with the Department's approval. Regarding the lettergram and letter of confirmation re same sent to Mr Lawes I would say that if they were addressed to Mr Lawes at Fort Pelly it would be some time before Mr Lawes would receive them at Punnichy, as Fort Pelly is an inland Post office and only receives and despatches mail once or twice a week. As there is no telegraphic communication with Fort Pelly the lettergram may possibly be held at Pelly station, seven miles distant from the Fort Pelly, until called for.

I will notify the Department when Mr Dance advises me of receipt of the cheque.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Sir:-

I have the honour to request that you give
the contents of this letter your consideration.

I have held the position as Teacher on the
above Reserve since May, 1919, and there has been quite a
difficulty for me to secure my cheque regarding same, owing to
fact that our new Agent (C.E. Bradbrooke Esq.,) has the cheque in
question come to him at the Agency.

I would that you would take into consideration
the fact that my residence is twenty-four miles from the Agency and
it is very seldom that I am down to it especially owing to the
fact that conveyances are not always convenient. Last quarter
I did not receive my cheque until August 13th, owing to the fact
that the Agent had neglected to send in my report but had simply
left it on file in the office at the Agency, now this quarter my
cheque has been at the Agency for two weeks, the weather is
inclement and I cannot go down for it, and therefore I am
compelled to wait the Agent's pleasure.

I understand that no other Teachers cheques
used to come to the Agency at all, but were sent direct to him
from Ottawa, and I have the honour to request that my cheques be
handled in the same way, for it does seem to me right that I should
have to wait five months for my salary especially now when we all
need all the necessary finance at our demands to make things meet.

I beg to state that I am not writing this
in the form of a complaint, but because I feel that you do not
understand the position, and therefore trust that in the future my request will receive your consideration.

Thanking you in anticipation of your attention regarding this matter,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

P.W. Fielden-Taylor.

Sir,

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Key Indian Day School No. 611

The Department has received and accepted the resignation of the teacher, Rev. J.M. Buck, effective July 1, 1943, and no further payment of salary should be made to him after that date.

Philip Phelan,

Ottawa,
June 16, 1943.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Key Indian Day School No. 611

In my memorandum of June 4, I advised you of the resignation of Rev. J.M. Buck, effective July 1, 1943. To succeed him the Department has appointed Rev. W.T. Browne at a salary of $90.00 a teaching month, plus bonus, effective September 1, 1943. I enclose copy of letter of appointment and the other documents will be forwarded to you when received.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, May 4, 1946.

Memorandum:

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Kay Indian Day School, No. 611.

Please note that the teacher, Reverend W. F. Browne, will give up duties at this school, effective July 1, 1946, and no further payment of salary should be made to him after that date.

For Deputy Minister.
Ottawa, June 7th, 1946.

Memorandum.

REPRESENTATIVE OF THE TREASURY

Re: Key Indian Day School, No. 611.

With reference to my memorandum of May 4th, Reverend W.F. Browne gave up duties as teacher effective May 31st, 1946. No further payment of salaries should be made to him.

Mrs. Margaret E. Browne has been appointed teacher for the month of June only at a salary of $105.00 a teaching month plus bonus.

Director
Kamsack, Saskatchewan,
November 12th, 1946.

Col. H. M. Jones,
Supervisor, Family Allowance

I have the honor to submit the following report on the Keye's Reserve Day School, visited February 3rd, 1931:

School Room: Not as clean as it might have been.

Children: Clean and healthy.

Tooth Brushes: Not used.

One comb provided for the use of all the children. Individual towels and cups provided for each child. Food at noon meal very good. Dishes - very few. Tables - clean. Lavatories - fair.

Examined all the children at school. Treated two who were ill at home - colds.

(Sgd) L.P. Wyatt, R.N.
Ottawa, March 16, 1931.

Sir:

Nurse Wyatt, in a report on her recent visit to the Keys Indian Day School, states that she found the school room "not as clean as it might have been", also that the tooth brushes supplied were not being used by the pupils, and that there were not sufficient dishes for the serving of the midday meal. She also states that there was only one comb provided for the use of all the children. She further states that she found the children clean and healthy and the food supplied at the noonday meal very good.

You should draw the attention of the teacher to the condition of the classroom, and he should see that it is kept in a cleanly condition. You may arrange for the purchase of a few extra combs and a small supply of dishes for the preparing and serving of the midday meal. No unnecessary expense should be incurred in these purchases, and accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded in the usual manner covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

EX'D.

Ottawa, April 4, 1936.

Dear Sir:

In a report on his visit to the Key's Day School on the 13th ultimo, Provincial School Inspector G. C. Andrews writes:

"Toilets are in extremely poor state of repair - there are holes in the wall of one, the roof has blown off the other, neither have doors. The present neglected condition of the outbuildings is, aside from hygienic conditions, a very poor example for the children."

The Department cannot understand why the toilets have been allowed to continue in the condition mentioned by the Inspector. Please let me have at once an estimate of the cost of repairing the present toilets or erecting new ones.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 4th instant, No. 117-4-5, in connection with the report of the school inspector to the effect that the outside toilets at the Key's Day School are in bad shape, I beg to say that his report is quite true. The roof of one of these buildings blew off during the winter and, as they should be moved, it was my intention to ask for authority to dig new holes and move them as soon as the frost goes out of the ground this spring. It cannot be done before that time. The cost will be about six dollars for material and labour. There have never been doors on these buildings and apparently it was not intended that there should be when they were built. If the Department intends to have doors put on it will cost another six dollars for material and labour.

In connection with this school, I would like to point out that the greatest need is exterior painting of the teacher's residence, which was asked for in the current year's estimates. I asked for an amount of $175.00 for this purpose and for kalsomine for the interior of the teacher's residence and class-room building. The Kalsomine is not essential and no damage will be done if delayed for another year, but the need of exterior painting is very urgent. Apparently it has been needed for some years as the shingles are all curled with the weather and the siding on the walls will have to be renewed before many years owing to the fact that it is so badly warped and twisted from need of paint over a period of years.

It will require at least $100.00 to make a good job of this exterior painting, and even more than that if I have to get outside labour at Union rates. There is no reason why the work could not be performed by an Indian, in which case $100.00 will be sufficient for both material and labour.

Your obedient servant,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

There should be a pump installed and the top should be properly finished with concrete to keep mice and gophers from falling into the well. Dear Sir:

He has been able, in other years, to give a fairly good meal of soup and vegetables when he had a good garden, but the garden this year was a complete failure. Regina, Sask., June 14, 1938.

Dear Sir,

I would like to submit the following report on the Pelly Agency.

Keys school and residence.

Both these buildings are very badly in need of paint, shingles, and wall board, are warping and deteriorating. I am informed that these buildings have not been painted for the last 12 or 15 years.

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa,
June 25, 1938.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Inspector Robertson in which he states that the Keys School and teacher's residence are badly in need of paint, shingles and wall board.

In preparing our estimates for the current fiscal year it was found possible to include an amount of $150.00 only for repairs, improvements and new equipment required at this school.

Please let me have a report stating how you consider this amount could be spent to the best advantage.

If the material for the work recommended by you costs more than $50.00 it will be necessary for you to send full particulars in order that purchase of same may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

J. P. B. Ostrander, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Kamsack, Sask.
Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of the 25th June last, in connection with repairs, improvements and new equipment at the Key's Day School, I have to say that the exterior of the teacher's residence is badly in need of paint and the interior of the class-room building is in need of kalsomine and varnish. The material for this work amounts to $43.75, or within the amount of $50.00 so I am making the purchase at once.

I think the balance of the money should be spent on excavating the cellar of the teacher's residence. This is now only a small hole in the ground and not of much use. The excavating and labour on the foundation can be done by Indians and will cost about forty dollars. The painting, kalsomining and varnishing can also be done by Indians and, after this is done, the balance of the $150.00 allowed, could be spent on tools and equipment for the use of the teacher instructing the boys and girls in carpenter work, sewing, and other useful work.

Yours truly,

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
August 5th, 1938.

EX'D.

The amount of $40.00 may be expended for labor in excavating the cellar of the teacher's residence.

Any balance left from the amount provided, viz., $150.00, may be expended in purchasing the tools and equipment mentioned in the last part of your letter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

Dear Sir:

I wish to inform you that I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. J.L. Bryant, Indian Agent, Pelly Agency, stating that shortly after I had inspected the teacher's residence at Key Indian Day School last Summer, they had a four inch rainfall and the walls of the basement caved in.

Mr. Bryant advises that in his opinion the only thing to do is to put in a full sized cement basement. The former basement was just a dugout and the house is on a cement surface foundation. He further states he has been trying to get a contractor to estimate a price on this ever since it happened but he has been unable to do so. However, he now has a price quotation from Alex Brass, an Indian from the File Hills Agency, and I am attaching copy hereto.

I will admit that putting the house on a cement foundation is probably the best method but I have no guarantee that Alex Brass is able to do this. Personally I think we had better get some logs to build a foundation, dig out the basement and line it with common boards because after all the teacher only needs a basement large enough to take care of his potatoes and provide room for the rain water cistern tank that is now in the dug-out basement. By banking the house up well it can be just as warm as if there were a cement basement.

I am just suggesting the above because it should cost much less than by doing it with cement.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

In reporting on his visit to the Keys Day School Mr. Morris writes as follows:

"Keys Day School - not locked - needs painting very badly and a couple of boards will have to be renewed on the back of the building. Both outside toilets are a disgrace. Agent Bryant was requested to build new ones and have them ready for the opening of classes next fall. Note: The school teacher was in Regina at a religious convention and left the school unlocked. I feel certain you visit the school regularly and the toilets should always be inspected and any repairs or cleaning should receive prompt attention. It is evident from Mr. Morris's remarks that very little attention has been given to this building. You might let me have an estimate of the cost of redecorating it.

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Sir,

During the last three years the number of pupils in this school has doubled itself. In addition, the cost of food has increased considerably.

I would therefore respectfully draw your attention to the fact that we still only get a $60 p.a. grant for school (mid-day) dinners. If this was sufficient three years ago it is not sufficient now. With careful use of garden produce & by my wife giving supervision to the meals we have managed to get $60 to last from Sept 1st to the present date. But the $60 is now exhausted, for we have 30 children to feed. We need a further grant for this term as well as an increased grant for next year.

We trust you to give this your sympathetic attention.

Extracts from Report of Mr. J. P. Gorszkowski, Superintendent of Schools, Kamisk, Saskatchewan, following his inspection of the Key Indian Day School, March 15, 1948.

Dr. Mansbridge has taken charge of Key Indian Day School in May, 1947. He has excellent academic standing but no teaching experience. After graduating with Ph.D. in London, he was employed as research technician in biology and foods. He specialized in biology.

Although Dr. Mansbridge is not acquainted with teaching techniques and newer methods in the primary grades, his work in the classroom is satisfactory. His kindly manner and attitude secure splendid classroom cooperation.

In reading, the selections studied were well analyzed, explained and discussed. The pupils read well but are somewhat deficient in comprehension. The writing and spelling as well as number work are well taught.

The classroom is too overcrowded. An additional building, with separate cloakrooms, cupboards, bookcases and washing facilities is strongly recommended. The old building could be converted into a kitchen, dining room and recreation hall. At present, noon lunch is served in crowded classrooms. An allowance of $60.00 per annum for noon meal is insufficient. It should be doubled, since at least 12 beginners are to start school this spring.

Sport equipment and facilities are inadequate. At least one football should be provided for winter months. Swings, teeter-totters would be very helpful for playground activities.

Health rules and general cleanliness should receive more emphasis. Considering the equipment available and the lack of classroom materials, Dr. Mansbridge is doing good work in this school.

Extract from Inspector Gerchynski's report on the Key Indian Day School dated November 8, 1948. Original on file 611-6

Both toilets should be replaced in the immediate future. Seats and floors should be scrubbed at least once a month.

November 25, 1948.

Mr. J.L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
Kamsack, Sask.

In a report dated November 18th, Inspector Gerohynski states that both the toilets at eh Asys Day School should be replaced at once.

Please let us know the cost that would be involved.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

PP/MGD
The children of this school have very few opportunities of taking part in healthy winter sports and I have considered the advisability of erecting an open air skating rink near the school.

A plot 30 feet by 100 feet could be levelled and flooded for approximately $20.00 a 3 foot high board fence around this would cost another $110.00 including material and labour. Once this work was done subsequent removal of snow and flooding when necessary would be done by the children themselves under Mr. Mansbridge's supervision. Norquay is approximately 12 miles from the Key school but few if any of the children from the Reserve would have the opportunity of skating there except on very rare occasions.

The Indian children love to skate and many develop into very good hockey players. The initial investment would be well worth while as the board fence could be built in sections, taken down and piled in the spring and used again for many winters to come.

If funds are available I would strongly recommend that this project be given favourable consideration.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent.

Please explain to the Indians that this small contribution is entirely due to the fact that we have had too many requests of a similar nature and we have expended our funds allotted for this purpose.

I would suggest that they do everything possible to raise some funds themselves as is being done at other Indian schools. Please advise me if you wish an accountable advance of $25.00 in this regard.

Re: Key School Toilets.

I have for acknowledgement your letter of November 25, 1948, regarding the toilets at Key Day School.

These toilets were upset on Halloween night and again by some of the grown up Indians about a week later. On the latter occasion the school door was wired up with barb wire. It appears that the Indians wanted to hold a box social and dance in the school on this certain night and were not allowed to do so, and they showed their displeasure in this manner. The toilets had not been properly replaced on the occasion of Inspector Gorchynski's visit.

I do not consider the toilets need to be replaced but they do need some repair. One requires a door and a new seat and both require some other minor repairs.

I would estimate that $30.00 for labour and material would put them in quite fair shape.

Next summer new pits should be dug and solid posts put in to which the toilets could be fastened to prevent them being upset so readily.

J. L. Bryant,

Date: May 20, 1949
The interior of the above noted school was damaged by fire recently. Mr. Mansbridge started a fire in the school box stove in the morning and left the building at 8:40 a.m. He claims one of the school girls arrived at the school about ten minutes later and found the walls near the stove on fire.

It is supposed that an overheated stove or pipes started the fire in part of the wall behind the stove. Some plaster had cracked and fallen from the wall which exposed the laths at this point.

Mr. Mansbridge thinks that a spark came through a very small bolt hole in the back of the stove and that this started the fire but I am of the opinion that the stove became overheated.

I would estimate that lath nails and lumber to repair the walls will cost approximately $20.00 and about 35 square yards of plaster will have to be replaced. This will require about 300 lbs of hardwall, 100 lbs of hydrated lime and 150 lbs. of finish and approximately 1 yard of sand. This material with the exception of the sand can be purchased locally from the Monarch Lumber Company at Norquay, Saskatchewan. Wages for labour will require approximately $100.00.

It is very difficult to secure the services of a competent plasterer and his charges would have to include transportation costs of his equipment from Kamsack to Key school a distance of 25 miles. The total cost of material and labour should not exceed $150.00.

I would like to have authority to proceed with this repair work as soon as possible after school closes in June.

The soft water cistern in the teachers residence is in very poor condition. I had Mr. Finnie, tinsmith, from Kamsack check this over recently with the hope that it could be repaired. However, it is so badly pitted that it is beyond repair.

A new cistern of the same size would cost approximately $60.00 installed.

I would recommend that the new cistern be installed.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Pelly Agency.

Re: Key Day School.
1949-1950 Estimates.

In our estimates provision was made for an addition to the teachers residence at Key Reserve at an estimated cost of $900.00, also a stable for the children's horses at an estimated cost of $1,000.00. I am now of the opinion that additional class room space is the most urgent requirement at the present time. This should be provided by building a 12 or 14 foot addition on the east end of the building. I would estimate roughly that the cost should not exceed $1,600.00 for labour and material. The present east end wall up to the ceiling would have to be removed with the exception of possibly 18 inches on each side. A rod could be put through from wall to wall at this point to add additional support.

The shingles on the present structure are showing signs of age and if this addition is approved I would suggest that these shingles be replaced by asbestos shingles.

The building should also be painted. There will be approximately 36 children this fall of school age on Key Reserve. The capacity of the school at present should not exceed 24 and this leaves very little open space not occupied by school desks teachers desk and a large box stove for heating purposes.

It would be appreciated if you would give these suggestions consideration and if they meet with your approval I will submit a plan of the addition, an estimate of the building material required and approximately what the construction of the addition would cost.

Re: Addition to Key Day School.

I wish to refer to Mr. C.A.F. Clark's letters of June 23, and June 25, in connection with the proposed addition to Key Day School.

I thought it advisable to estimate for an addition 16' x 22' instead of 15' x 22' as there would be very little additional cost due to a certain amount of loss of material in the 15' addition.

The estimate prepared by the Monarch Lumber Co. Ltd. of Norquay, is approximately correct but in a job of this kind where alterations are being made to the present structure a small amount of extra material may be required. It is noted that there is an error in the size and number of the windows, we require 8 windows 26x30 instead of 4 24x26. I feel satisfied that an additional $50.00 would cover any extras that might be required.

The Porcupine Lumber Co of Pelly, Saskatchewan have been asked to submit an estimate but this has not yet been received, in any case Norquay is the closest point to Key Reserve and I am of the opinion that somewhat better building material is supplied by the Monarch Lumber Co. Ltd.

I expect to receive a tender in writing for the labour this week from Mr. Ole Anderson of Norquay. He advised me today that he would first discuss the matter with his son, but he thought they could do the work for approximately $850.00 which would include painting the building inside and out. This would also include insulation of the ceiling with shavings that are obtainable in Norquay at $2.00 per truck load. We would have to supply the shavings and 50 lbs. of lime at the school site.

Mr. Anderson will supply necessary sand and gravel for the cement work at no extra cost. Charges for trucking lumber etc. from Norquay, should not exceed $25.00.

It is very difficult to obtain competent carpenters for this type of work a considerable distance from town and I doubt very much if I can obtain another tender for the work which must be completed before September 5th. Mr. Anderson is reported to be a reliable workman and I consider his tender for the labour is fair and reasonable and should be accepted forthwith in order that he may be advised and ready to start work as soon as the material is purchased.

J. L. Bryant,
Superintendent,
Pelly Agency

Dear Mr. Bryant:

Since returning to Ottawa I have reviewed the file of Key School and studied my photographs and diagrams.

I can see how it will be difficult to place 12 windows along one wall of the enlarged school. I notice that you are adding only four windows and that these will probably be in the new extension. That will make eight windows in line along the 46 foot wall. Do you not think that it would be possible to increase the number of windows to 10 by adding two more in the present blank space between the existing four windows and the cloak-room? Indeed 12 windows along one wall would come closer to giving the desirable fenestration ratio.

The cost for additional windows during the present extensive alterations would be a small fraction of the total. If they are omitted now, and we have complaints later about the lighting, the expense will be much greater.

Yours sincerely,

C.A.F. Clark,
Educational Survey Officer.

Ottawa, October 6, 1924.

Sir:

His Lordship the Bishop of Qu'Appelle has recommended that a teacher's residence be provided to replace the present old building at the Keys Indian Day School. I shall be pleased to have your recommendation regarding this request. If you are of the opinion that a new building should be erected, please intimate the type of same and state the approximate cost, also whether you could undertake the purchase of the material and arrange for the necessary labour, etc. It may be too late in the season to undertake the erection of the building this fall, but, in order to give consideration to His Lordship's request, I shall be pleased to have your views on the same, giving full information as requested.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant informing me that the Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle has made a request that a residence be provided for the day school teacher on the Key Reserve. This school as you are aware is a very small one and I have always been reluctant in spending money on this institution. The present residence of the teacher is really a poor affair and I would be prepared to recommend that $3,500.00 be placed in the estimates to meet the expense of building a house for the teacher.

I find that the Pelly Estimates have mailed to you, and I would be glad if you will place this amount in the estimates when they reach you.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham
Indian Commissioner

Ottawa, December 29, 1924.

Mr. Paget,

Would you kindly let me know whether we can provide from this year's estimates the sum of $1500.00 for a school and teacher's residence on the Keys reserve, and also $1500.00 for a day school on Day Stars reserve. Mr. Graham represents that these expenditures are advisable.

D.S.G.I.A.

Requirements at Keys School have been noted in 1926-27 Estimates.
January 13, 1925.

Memorandum:

With reference to your memorandum hereunder, I have to report that funds could be found from this year's appropriation for a $1800.00 school and teacher's residence at Keys and a like amount for a day school at Day Stars, if it is your wish that they be proceeded with at once.

I have written to Mr. Graham, asking him to submit a definite proposal with reference to Day Stars and I was awaiting his letter relative to the situation at Keys, before taking any action. This was agreed upon at the time of our recent conference.

There is no item for these schools in the preliminary draft of the Estimates, 1925-26.

Russell J. Turner,
Supt. of Indian Education.
Sir:

Since returning home I have made enquiries regarding the school house and teacher's residence on Kev's Reserve in the Belly Agency. Mr. Inspector Christianson, who has just visited this school a short time ago, tells me that the house is absolutely unfit for occupation; that it was built by me some twelve years ago; built of logs, and at a small cost. The logs are rotten and the building is really beyond repair. No further money should be spent on it. I would, therefore, ask for an amount of $2,000.00 to erect a log cottage with a lean-to kitchen. If the money can be advanced in order to get the logs out this winter, so much the better.

The school house is not in very bad shape. A new floor should be put in, and there is too much light owing to the fact that there are windows on both sides of the building. You will notice that $100.00 was placed in the Estimates for 1925-26 for general repairs to this building.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Ostrander:

No doubt it is quite unusual for you to hear from the wife of a missionary but I'm afraid I just cannot keep still any longer and let you continue to think that the teachers provided by our Canadian Government on Indian Reserves "are good little houses, for which many a person in Regina would be very thankful."

In the first place I very much doubt if one person out of ten or even a hundred in Regina, would be thankful to live in any house (even the best one on College Avenue or Angus Crescent) if it was not here on Key Reserve. In the second place they wouldn't live in this house the way it is but would soon fit it up into a decent house—which we would have done long before this if it were our own house. It is no wonder that the Bishop cannot get missionaries.

Morquay, Sask.,
Jan. 29/46
to stay here more than two or three years. No man could stand such conditions any longer.

Last spring when you were here I had you look at the basement to see how the house is away from the foundation with cracks large enough to put your finger into. At the time you said that would be very easily fixed—but is it fixed? No! Everything on the shelves froze the first cold snap and each can has to be thawed out before we can use it. The cellar is frozen too. The floors are so cold all day that I can't stand the cold on my feet and for weeks have been suffering terribly from chilblains. Unless one has suffered from it, one has no idea how agonizing it becomes.

No doubt you will say that it is not the policy of the Government to improve teacherages especially during 1946. In that case they shouldn't expect people to live in them. It was patriotic to put up with such conditions but my patriotism is tested
beyond endurance, these last three years,
especially when every citizen of Canada
is not and couldn't even imagine living
under such conditions as these. People
who are responsible for the building of
such places should have to live in
them.

There should be a full-sized cement
basement under this house with a furnace,
and good cistern. The house should be
enlarged and some clothes closets and
cupboards built. There isn't a room large
enough to contain both our Chesterfield and
piano. The latter is in a bedroom which
serves also as serving room. You can
imagine how much space there is left in
a room 12x12'.

The walls should all be insulated as
there is frost on them and the beds have
to be kept away as I found the bedding all
wet when it touched the wall. Last winter
ruined one end of my cedar chest. I kept
it a good bit under from the wall but the veneer is all cracked and coming off one end. I certainly feel badly about it as it was an expensive chest and couldn't be replaced in these days.

You have my permission to use this letter to forward to the Department of Indian Affairs in Ottawa or I may even write directly to Ottawa.

Mrs. Browne and I both consider the work amongst our Indians very important and I don't think you will find any missionary who work harder than we do as we have given of our time and talent, unstintedly to this work and pray incessantly that God may use us to further this work any way we can. But it is hardly necessary to have to live in such a house, to be a good missionary.

Sincerely yours,

TEACHER. Rev. W. H. English.

Methods and Success.

Mr. English's manner and qualifications are evidently much better adapted to white pupils and those of more advanced grades, but without making a special effort to adapt them to his present work they are unsuitable and unsuccessful. The teacher appears to have adopted but few devices for drawing out his pupils, leading them out of their timidity and self-consciousness and inducing them to think and speak. The pupils respect their teacher highly, but hold him in such awe that they cannot be induced to speak in any case above a whisper. I fear that Mr. English's present duties as teacher will never enlist his interest to any large extent. It is but fair to say so far as the examination is concerned, that the teacher stated that all his brightest pupils happened to be absent on the day of inspection.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR CROMIE ON THE LITTLE PINE DAY SCHOOL.

Teacher,- Rev.W.H.English

The discipline of this school is good but this appears to be maintained by the somewhat stern attitude of the teacher, who appears to be held in awe by the pupils. He does not seem able to get them to speak out and I found it almost impossible to get an answer of any kind from the pupils.

I noticed, also, that at times he makes use of the Cree language in school and the opening exercises are conducted by him both in Cree and English.

From the long experience Mr. English appears to have had in teaching in white schools and from observation of his methods in school I can only conclude that he is more adapted to teaching in a school for white boys where the strictest discipline has to be maintained.

I can only report that so far as I was able to observe the pupils of this school are making very little progress.

I beg to advise you that the following is the menu for the midday meal at the day schools.

Poundmaker School. They are given either bean, rice, pea or barley soup and either beef or bacon with two biscuits. The meat is usually cooked with the soup.

Littlepine School. This is the same as the Poundmaker School with the addition of rice pudding occasionally.

Moosomin School. This is the same as at the Poundmaker School.

Red Pheasant School. At this school they have pea, bean, barley and rice soup with vegetable soup once a week. They are also given beef and bacon with potatoes and two biscuits.

At all the schools they are given tea with milk and sugar.

Re. the driver at Red Pheasant School receiving his meal. This man received his meal in payment for cutting wood and weeding the garden and doing any little jobs that were required to be done. This was discontinued last fall.

Dear Mr. Scott,

2nd Little Pines School, I believe I answered this at once, saying (a) that Rev. D. Macdonald is not strictly a "returned soldier". Sir,

I am in receipt of Mr. M.B. Edwards resignation as Teacher at Little Pines, and would recommend that it be accepted, as he has been teaching by substitute since last spring on account of sickness from which he cannot recover. Mrs. Edwards resignation was forwarded to you some time ago.

I am of the opinion that the Department would be justified in closing up this school as well as the one on Poundmakers, there are 270 Indians on these two Reserves and it is rare to find more than six children in either school at any time which makes the cost per capita nearly double what it costs at the Boarding Schools, and the results certainly do not justify it, if anything the Poundmakers school is less use than the other, they are both used principally for missionary work, the education of the children is secondary, and the Indians simply won't send their children or make any effort to assist the schools and when wood is required it is a case of hold up and a fight to get them to bring it. The buildings at Poundmakers are rented from the Catholic Church at $75.00 a quarter and the church is used as the school.

Dear Sir:

Referring to my visit to Ottawa in Sept. last and the interview which you kindly favoured me, the question of the Little Pine Day School was discussed, and, as the Department did not consider it advisable to undertake the re-opening of the school, you kindly allowed me to make the attempt on my own responsibility and at my own expense. It was understood that the school buildings would be placed at my disposal.

On my arrival from the East, I found that due instructions had been sent to your agent, and I have the pleasure of stating that Mr. McDonald has been most willing to assist me in every way in his power.

I was not able to make complete arrangements for opening the school until towards the end of the year, and the school was only actually opened in the beginning of January. I am forwarding herewith, the Return for Quarter ended March 31st, which shows an enrolment of 26 pupils, and an average attendance of 23 1/12ths. We could easily have had an enrolment of over 30, but, with the number that we have had the school room has been pretty well filled.

For teacher I secured the services of Miss A.L. Cunningham, one of the best Indian school teachers that I know of, and, under her management, the school is admirably conducted.

In carrying on the school, I have furnished a mid-day meal, and in every way endeavoured to conduct it according to the Department's system of conducting an Improved Day School.

In conversation with you regarding the school, there was mention made of keeping a few temporary or weekend boarders. I had forgotten, however, at the time, that this school building does not provide accommodation such as the Mistawasis and a few other schools do, so that the idea had to be abandoned, and I found that it was necessary to have a driver in order to secure a regular attendance.

When the Department decides to take over the school, as I hope and trust it will, I shall be prepared to furnish a statement of expenditure, and I think the Department will find that the expenditure has not been expensive and that the results are satisfactory.

Sir,

I am in receipt of Department letter No 105-2-1 regarding the Little Pines Day School. The Ven Archdeacon J.A. Mackey, left two days ago for the Carleton Agency and will be away two weeks so that I will not be able to get the Statement of expenditure for the Department till he returns, but beg to report as follows on this school.

A very careful annual report was made on this School which the Department has no doubt seen by this time and while at Little Pines this week I spent a whole forenoon in the school and if anything it is improving, there were 22 children present, their progress is very good, the discipline, school room appearance and condition of the children is exceptional.

I have thought this matter over carefully and would recommend to the Department, that the school be left under the direct charge of the Ven Archdeacon and that the Department supply the necessary school supplies and pay him a lump sum for the running of the school based on the cost per month, of the four months that the school has been open, he could send his reports etc through this office in the regular way and come under inspection, but to have practically a free hand in running the school.

My reasons for the above recommendation are firstly that I would not like to see this school again deteriorate to the regular Day school standard, which it would naturally do, as the Department do not assist and clothe these children and people or feed them the way it is done in this school. I was at the Little Pines day school on the 23rd with Mr Veazey Provincial School Inspector for that district and made a thorough inspection as well as looking into the requirements for the school, the Inspector was more than surprised at this school and informed me that there were very few Rural white schools that could class up to it.

The well has gone bad and the water is not fit to use, the Archdeacon thought it needed cleaning and had a Well digger out, cleaned the well and went down an additional ten feet, but it seems no better, this item was paid for by the Archdeacon but has not been included in his statement, the cost was $50.00.

Sir,

On the 11th while at Little Pines Reserve, I spent the afternoon, with Miss Cunningham at the Little Pines Day school, I arrived there unexpectedly, so that I found the school as it actually works each day and it was a credit to any school, the work of the pupils, condition and appearance of the children and school was a treat. There were 29 children present and three absent and the attendance had been almost perfect.

My chief reason for this letter is, regarding the Salary of Miss Cunningham, which is at present $600.00 and as I understand the grade of wages for teachers is $600.00 and where they have qualifications $800.00, Miss Cunningham informed me that she did not have qualifications, but her experience and ability and training as a Nurse are certainly worth the better salary. She is without doubt the best I have yet seen in the way of teachers in Indian schools and in my estimation is worth several pf the average teachers holding written qualifications and with neither the knowledge or ability to properly teach Indian Children, which after all is the principle requirement in teaching the Indians and I would strongly recommend that Miss Cunningham be paid as a qualified teacher.

With regard to the School driver, I would like authority to increase him from $1.50 to $2.00 per day as his work is really worth $2.50, he has to drive 14 miles to pick up the children and bring them to school usually arriving at 8.30 and has to make the 14 miles again to take the children home after four, at the Consolidated school at Paynton near the reserve, the drivers are getting $4.00 a day for the same work.

I might add that Miss Cunningham has made no protest about her salary, but it is just a case of, if she got a better offer she would take and she is one of the teachers that is worth keeping and deserves encouragement for the work she is doing, the condition and personal appearance of the children are as important as the actual school work and both are far above average in her school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

She has had considerable experience in teaching and appears to me to be a very excellent teacher. She has a lot of good common sense and exerts a very beneficial influence over the people on the reserve who appear to have every confidence in her. The attitude of the Indians towards the school is an evidence of this. They are very proud of their school and are giving it their hearty support.

Miss Cunningham is assisted in her work by Miss Edwards who acts as assistant teacher, and Miss Faithful who is a missionary worker. It is encouraging to find a Day School with such a good record of attendance, the average attendance for the quarter ending September 30th being 31 out of an enrollment of 32 pupils.

(Sgd) W. Murray
Inspector of Ind. Affairs

Dear Mr. Graham:

There are three Day Schools, viz:- Little Pines, Red Pheasant, and Thunderchilds, and the Thunderchild Boarding School situated at Delmas, Saskatchewan.

LITTLE PINES DAY SCHOOL

I visited this school on Saturday, September 27th. There were no children in attendance. I examined the school register and noted the condition of the buildings. The buildings are all badly in need of painting and interior decorating, and, acting on your instructions I arranged to have this work done and it should now be well under way. There are 32 pupils on the register, 19 boys and 13 girls. There is no difficulty experienced in getting a regular attendance at this school; all the children attend unless prevented by illness. Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 2nd instant, relative to the appointment of an assistant teacher and matron to succeed Miss M. Brown at the Little Pines Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that, in our letter to His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan of the 2nd ultimo, we should have requested that the services of a suitable person be secured, instead of a "qualified teacher." She should be able to assist the teacher generally and, if required, take a class of the smaller children for short periods during the day. She should also be responsible for the preparation of the midday meal for the children.

LITTLE PINE DAY SCHOOL.

This school is on the Little Pine reserve and is an Anglican Day school with Miss A.L. Cunningham in charge and assisted by Miss I.M. Feilhfull, who has been there now for over a year. They are both first class teachers of Indian Schools and handle all the duties together and are both very capable as field matrons.

The attendance at this school is not as big as it was, some have gone to Boarding school to finish and others have finished and left, but it is expected that enough new pupils will enroll this spring to bring the attendance up again.

A school driver is also employed and makes about a seven mile circuit twice a day delivering the children to and from school, he is an Indian of the reserve and is willing and prompt at his duties.

With the exception of a little interior decorating the buildings are in first class shape.

The progress at this school is exceptional and teaching of the children and the efforts of the staff is more than visible in the homes of the reserve particularly in the homes of the children who are attending and taking a pride in their habits and appearance.

MEMO FOR FILE:

LITTLE PINES INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is located in the diocese of Saskatoon and conducted under the auspices of the Right Reverend W. T. Hallam, M.A., D.D., 628 University Drive, Saskatoon, Sask.
Little Pine Day School.

This is an Anglican Day school on the Little Pine reserve with a steady attendance of around 40 children and as day schools go could not be duplicated.

Miss A.L. Cunningham is Teacher in charge with Miss Jones as assistant; as the school building is not large enough for all the Pupils, the classes are divided and the Junior classes are held in the children's dining room in the residence.

The buildings consist of Residence, School building and a small two stall barn, now used as Garage, they are all frame, the first two have full basement of cement and have hot air furnaces, well built and well lighted.

There is no water supply and water has to be hauled for all purposes, and all attempts so far to get water have failed.

A driver is employed now only during the winter months or up to April 15th.

This was an improved school with a hot noon meal but the supply was discontinued by the Department, since when the Church Authorities, Teacher and Indians have managed to donate enough to still give a partial meal.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MR. A. R. BROWN, PROVINCIAL SCHOOL INSPECTOR, DATED NOVEMBER 27, 1935, ON HIS INSPECTION OF THE LITTLE PINES INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

Original on No. 105-2-6.

ANNIE LETITIA CUNNINGHAM - Salary $900
MARGARET M.R. ARMITAGE - $600.

Miss Armitage is doing very well. Miss Cunningham is satisfactory as matron and as contact between the school and the parents. Her experience stands her in good stead.

Miss Cunningham has engaged Miss Cordelia Winnifred Elizabeth Stewart, B.A., Int. 1st Class (Sask.) to act as her substitute in actual classroom instruction in Grades I - III. Miss Stewart is doing excellent work. I consider this a satisfactory arrangement.

I understand that Miss Stewart has been engaged by Miss Cunningham to substitute for her in actual class teaching without consultation with the Department. With regard to the latter point, I have no interest, but I beg to repeat that the present arrangement has greatly improved instruction without increase in cost to the Department. Miss Cunningham, on account of her long experience, is valuable as a general matron and as the contact between the parents and the school. She is also able to give valuable advice to the other teacher. Miss Stewart is doing excellent work. In my opinion much better work than Miss Cunningham could do - in the junior room. I would recommend that this arrangement be given formal approval for, say, a year. The situation could be reviewed on my next inspection. I understand that Miss Cunningham pays Miss Stewart $35 per month out of her own salary.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF MR. INSPECTOR MURISON, DATED JANUARY 7, 1936, WHICH ACCOMPANIED THE ABOVE REPORT.

Miss Cunningham is not only a good teacher but an excellent manager and one who has made her personality very effective in the living conditions and behaviour of the Indians on this Reserve. Dear Sir:

Thank you for your very encouraging letter of 7th February. The great interest shown by the Indian Department during the last two or three years makes one wish that we were beginning instead of nearing the end of our work here. We really have our work planned out until 1940, as that would give time to leave the Handicrafts fairly well established. Work amongst adult Indians is a long slow process.

Though we always had a certain amount of satisfaction in our small corner, the reserve as a whole was so backward and official opinion so unfavourable at first, that things seemed almost hopeless to those who were bent on improvement. It gives one real hope for the future to know that the Indian Department now expects the workers on the reserves to achieve something. It used to be so easy to blame the poor wretched Indian for all failures.

You will be interested to know that this month we received our first order from England - for nine dozen bead mats. If we can continually raise the standard of work and secure another order next year, this opening might develop into a permanent market. We are quite pleased with the beadwork that is coming in now.

The history of this industry is quite interesting. Beginning with one or two, now all but the very old women
are working, and our ex-pupils especially are learning very quickly. Two years ago the "Arts and Crafts Society" of Saskatoon gave us a start by supplying beads and buying most of the mats made, but as they can take only a limited number, we are continually on the lookout for other markets.

The women and also the men take real pride in this work. This is a step towards the community spirit, the lack of which retards progress. There is a full-time job for someone, for years to come, if the lack of co-operation is to be replaced by a wider outlook and unselfish work for the reserve and race. No doubt as the Indians get beyond the stage of semi-starvation and discover how to make a decent living, this wider outlook will come.

Yours truly,

A. L. Cunningham.

Dear Miss Cunningham:
