Dear Sir:

I have to inform you that Miss Little, who came in September, to take charge of the senior room, expects to be married next Saturday, 23rd December. I do not know if it will be in order for her to finish out the year here. If not, I would suggest that Mrs. Warden, who is an experienced High School teacher and now teaching these Public School grades in her own home, would be the best to fill the gap for the remainder of the year. January is a difficult month in which to make a change, for one used to a steam-heated house, feels the intense cold, and nearly two months of this school year has already been wasted, with a teacher totally inexperienced in Indian work, and probably unfitted for it. Mrs. Warden has all the necessary qualifications for the school work, and having already gained considerable influence over the Indian women, the personal touch with the children would be a great asset in her future social service work here. If a teacher is able to teach only the school curriculum, the Indian child is better left uneducated, for character building is the essential thing.

If the Indian Department refuses to appoint Mrs. Warden, rather than hazard the loss of more time in the class-room, we would suggest carrying on ourselves, as we did before, with excellent results. We do not wish to do this for there are so many important duties on the reserve. The bead-work is developing into quite an industry and we are receiving more orders than we can fill. Then the women are learning to card wool for the surrounding farmers and the machines have been busy all fall. All this with many other duties needs constant supervision and advice. The adult India learns slowly.

Yours truly,

(Signed) A.L.Cunningham.
Some comment is desirable in connection with the suggestion in Miss Cunningham's letter that they could carry on for the remainder of the term without a teacher, replacing Miss Little, if the Department so desire. The only alternative Miss Cunningham would have in that case would be Miss Faithful, who is engaged by Miss Cunningham, and who does not exist, officially, so far as the Department is concerned. Miss Cunningham's suggestion might lead the Department to believe that one appointee could do the work of this school. Such would be impossible, unless we are prepared to drop a considerable amount of the useful work which is being done. I do think, however, that when Miss Cunningham retires, the appointment at this school should be a man and wife, similar to the arrangement recently made at the Thunderchild's Bay School, but this is for future consideration.

With regard to appointing Mrs. Warden, temporarily to complete the term, I have only to say that I believe Mrs. Warden, wife of the Farming Instructor at the Little Pine and Poundmaker's Reserves, would be an excellent teacher, and she is, even now, helping some with the Little Pine School work, without remuneration. Mrs. Warden is just as strong-minded as Miss Cunningham, and would not likely be willing to stand aside in everything, any more than Miss Little has been, consequently there would soon be a clash, if she were appointed. I am also very doubtful of the Department considering appointing her, unless the need for a change was very urgent, and no one suitable could be found.

Yours truly,

J.F.B. Ostrander,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing, herewith, a copy of a letter received from Miss A.L. Cunningham, of the Little Pine Day School, in connection with the marriage of Miss Frances B. Little, who was appointed teacher at that school for the current school year, on authority of Departmental letter 106-2-1, dated 22nd August, 1939.

I do not know how the Department will view the matter of this lady's marriage, or whether they will consider that, in the best interests of the school, she should be asked for her resignation, consequently I am referring the case to you for your consideration and your recommendation. She told me, yesterday, in conversation, that her prospective husband is a teacher at some white school in Saskatchewan, and that he will continue with his present appointment, after their marriage. She would like to continue at the Little Pine school, at least for the remainder of this term and that, as far as she is concerned, her marriage will make no difference in the present arrangement. If there is to be any change, it will be for the Department to decide.

I do not wish to offer any criticism of the work of Miss Cunningham at this school, nor of her attitude in the case under consideration, but it is only fair to Miss Little that I should point out that her work in the class-room has been very satisfactory. She has not shown anything particular in connection with the other work being done at this school, and when I spoke to her of this, yesterday, she informed me that she is very interested in the other work, but that Miss Cunningham does not permit her to take part in it as she would like to, consequently, to avoid any possibility of friction, she has not taken any active part. Knowing Miss Cunningham, I feel sure this statement is true.

I firmly believe that both these ladies are trying to do their best, in the interests of the Indian children, but it is evident that their viewpoints clash in some matters in connection with the work. I pointed out to Miss Little that Miss Cunningham has been doing, and is still doing, good work at this school and that she is, to some extent in charge. Miss Little says she understands this, and has been overlooking some things which were unpleasant for her, on this account, and that she will continue to do so, if the Department decides to let her complete her term, notwithstanding her marriage.

As Miss Cunningham will not be in the work much longer, and Miss Little wants to remain in the work, for some years, if acceptable to the Department, and I believe will be useful in the work, I would not recommend asking her resignation. I make this statement because I do not think that any teacher would be completely acceptable to Miss Cunningham unless she was prepared to stand aside and be completely overshadowed by Miss Cunningham, and I do not think this is the type of people we want in our service.

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Dear Sir:

Re: Little Pine Day School, Battleford.

I am attaching copy of a letter from Miss Cunningham, teacher at the above school, advising that Miss Little, in charge of the senior room, expects to be married on December 23rd, together with copy of a letter from Mr. Ostrander on the matter.

You will note that Miss Cunningham states that two months of the present year has already been wasted with a teacher totally inexperienced in Indian work, and suggests that Mrs. Warden, wife of our Farming Instructor, be engaged to finish out the term. You will also note in Mr. Ostrander's comments that he points out that Miss Little's work in the classroom has been very satisfactory; that she has not shown anything in particular with regard to the other work being done in the school, and when he spoke to her in this regard she informed him that she was very interested in the other work, but that Miss Cunningham does not permit her to take part in it as she would like to, and to avoid friction, she has not taken any active part. He also considers that if Mrs. Warden were appointed there would soon be a clash.

You will also note Miss Cunningham's remark, "If a teacher is able to teach only the school curriculum, the Indian children are better left uneducated, for character building is the essential thing", and I must say I am in whole-hearted accord with her on this matter. Miss Cunningham has been an outstanding teacher and leader. One has only to visit her reserve and meet the Indians to realize the actual work she has done. As Mr. Ostrander states, Miss Cunningham is a very strong-minded woman. She could not have made the success she has had

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
she been otherwise. At the same time, I have found Miss Cunningham very amenable to suggestions, always ready to adopt any policy which she believes is for the welfare of the Indians. For instance, when I first came on here, I found that she was devoting practically all her time to working through the men for improvement of conditions. I suggested to her the idea of devoting more time to the women. She was very doubtful at that time, but quite willing to try it out, and she has on a number of occasions since expressed regret that she did not take up women's work earlier. She is now devoting considerable time to it, with splendid success.

Mrs. Warden is also strong-minded. She holds a first-class teacher's certificate, in fact is a B.A. She has been doing excellent work among the women of the reserves and has been assisting Miss Cunningham in the work at the school. I do not believe there would be any clash between Miss Cunningham and Mrs. Warden, as both Mr. and Mrs. Warden have worked with Miss Cunningham since coming to the reserve. They understand each other well and I feel they would both take particular pains to see that no friction developed.

It is very apparent from Miss Cunningham's letter that she does not feel that Miss Little is of very much assistance to her. I therefore feel that if it were possible to allow Mrs. Warden to carry on for the balance of the term, it would be advisable to let Miss Little go. If this is not possible, however, I feel it would be better to allow Miss Little to carry on her duties, as otherwise we would be faced with the problem of securing another teacher who would probably have less experience than Miss Little. With regard to Miss Cunningham's suggestion that she and Miss Faithfull could carry on, I consider this would be a great mistake, as it would prevent Miss Cunningham from carrying on the work she is doing, which, in my opinion, is of the first importance.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 23rd instant and also certain correspondence relating to the employment or re-employment of a teacher at the above noted school, attached thereto.

I am particularly anxious that we should not get our wires crossed with respect to educational and welfare effort on this particular reserve. I am naturally anxious, also, that in the employment of teachers we should adhere as strictly as circumstances will permit to the departmental regulations now in force.

I have pointed out on a number of occasions to our inspectors and Indian agents that we are not permitted, under existing regulations, to employ married women as teachers, other than women whose husbands are physically incapacitated and unable to support them. This regulation has been strictly observed throughout the government service but seems to be somewhat difficult to apply in the employment of Indian day school teachers. The regulation was passed by the Government in the interests of those who were in receipt of unemployment relief and naturally anxious to become self-supporting. A great deal of the trouble that occurred at Montreal Lake was due to our inability to pay Mrs. Stenhouse for the social service work she undertook and accomplished on that reserve. You may be interested to learn that the claims of this woman for remuneration have been carefully reviewed by the Director of this Branch, the Superintendent of Medical Services and the Treasury officials during the last week, but, under the regulations now in force, no remuneration could be allowed her. In order to employ Mrs. Warden at the Little Pine Day School, the officials of the Training Division would be called upon to declare that her husband is permanently disabled and no longer capable of supporting her. We have no evidence before us that such is the case.

The conditions at the Little Pine School are, as you know, somewhat unusual. At that school we have a pupil enrolment of 23 and an average attendance substantially lower than that figure. We have three teachers employed to provide instruction for these pupils - two of whom are paid by the Department. In view of the fact that Miss Cunningham is likely to resign at the end of the present academic year,

Dr. Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.
the conditions at this particular school should be carefully reviewed and discussed fully and in detail with the church authorities. My own opinion is that a first class teacher should be employed to give instruction to the 29 pupils. I mean by instruction the usual academic course plus vocational instruction for boys and elementary domestic science - sewing, crochet work, weaving, etc., for girls.

If, in addition to this teacher, it is felt that a social service worker should be employed, application should be made for such an appointment. If, however, there is a farming instructor employed on the reserve, it would be exceedingly difficult to persuade those responsible for such appointments that a social service worker is really needed. The point I am anxious to emphasize is that such work should not be, and must not be, charged to our educational appropriation. Such charges cannot be recognized by the Treasury officials as legitimate charges on the educational appropriation, and I am afraid that someone either in this office or on the field is likely to get into trouble when the full facts of the case become disclosed. We are reminded here almost constantly by Treasury officials that each appropriation appearing in the estimates must be spent, and spent only, for the purpose for which it is voted by Parliament. If a social service worker were employed at the Little Pine reserve, I am disposed to think that such a worker would come under the direction of the General Superintendent of Agencies. We have no such workers that I am aware of at any reserve throughout the Dominion.

In respect to the immediate problem confronting us, may I point out again that it would help us here if our agents did not recommend the employment of married women. The agents should know by this time that in asking us to employ such women they are asking us to ignore existing regulations. I have discussed with the officials here very fully the case of Miss Little, who has been until now in charge of the senior room at the Little Pine school, and who was, as I understand it, married on December 23. If we were adhering strictly to the regulations, this woman should be immediately dismissed. In view of all the circumstances, however, I am inclined to think that she should be permitted to continue with her teaching duties until the end of the academic year, on the distinct understanding that she cannot under any circumstances be re-employed after that date.

I am fully aware of the splendid program undertaken and carried forward by Miss Cunningham on the Little Pine reserve. Work such as this should be, in my judgment, encouraged and extended. It is welfare work in the truest and best sense and is indispensable if our Indians are to become self-reliant and self-supporting. Under existing regulations, however, it cannot be linked up directly with educational effort and unless our officials in the field can persuade the Government or the Civil Service Commission or the Treasury officials, or all three, that the regulations should be changed, we should in all fairness keep these two services on our reserves separate and apart.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

In reply to your letter asking for the nomination of a teacher for the Little Pine Indian Day School, I beg to submit the name of Ahab Spence, now resident at Stanley, Sask.

At once on receipt of your letter advertisements were inserted in the Battleford and Saskatoon papers for a week. Mr. Spence is the only applicant. You are well aware of the shortage of teachers in this province. Last year Normal School students were sent out with only three weeks training in some cases.

Mr. Spence has Grade XII, and requires only four more subjects to gain his B.A. from the University of Saskatchewan. For the last few years he has been seasonal school teacher at Stanley so he has had some teaching experience although he has no certificates as a qualified teacher. Your Agent at Punnichy, Mr. R.S. Davis, under whom he has served at Stanley, has written highly commending his work and his influence among the Indians. At Stanley he has been teaching grades 1 - 4. At Little Pine the grades at present are 1 - 6. Mr. Spence's academic work at the University would indicate that he is capable of teaching all the grades.

Mr. Spence graduated from your Elkhorn School and came to Saskatoon where he held his own in the University and the College, taking an active part in the athletic life there. He is a fine type of man. He speaks Cree fluently. He is thirty-one years of age and has a wife and child. In his application he says: "Being a native myself I have the good of the Indian at heart. I will try to translate this desire of mine into the better language of deeds".

Your Agent at Battleford, Mr. Ostrander, knows about him and has received testimony about him. I am convinced that Mr. Spence's appointment to the School would be a great help to the life of the whole Reserve as well as the School. It is with entire confidence that I nominate him for the post. He will be available to begin work about Sept. 1st.

Dear Sir:

I am contemplating on completing a B.A. degree course from the University of Saskatchewan at the earliest possible time. I only need two classes that I must take intra-murally during a summer session. The session is of six weeks' duration, and costs about one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) per session. My academic record is as follows so far. Graduated from Emmanuel College, Saskatoon, in 1937, with a Licentiate in Theology with an average of 69.8%. Since that time I have taken extra-murally at my own expense the following classes from the University of Saskatchewan, with results as follows:

| History 24.B Division B | Philosophy 52. Division C. |

Last year I planned on attending the University Summer Session, but was not able to do so because I had to take my wife to the hospital early in June at North Battleford, and the following month proceeded to Prince Albert to have X-rays taken of Mrs. Spence. Next month I must again take my wife to a Prince Albert Hospital...for an addition to our family.

As you know, babies cost money, and I'm not getting any younger. I would like to get my B.A. as soon as possible. Dear Sir:

I want to thank you for your letter of the 14th instant, which I have just received.

The Report Cards will be welcome here. I tried to institute the idea the first year I was here. On the whole it went over fairly well, but some parents refused to sign it as they thought that there was a "catch init somewhere". But I am willing to co-operate with the Department with that splendid step in Indian Education.

I am also wondering why the Department will not go further and institute "promotion Certificates" and proper Commencement Exercises at the end of each academic year to which all parents and friends will be invited, and the Inspector of Indian Agencies or the Indian Agent would be the Master of Ceremonies. One realizes of course that the Inspector is a busy man, and so is the Agent but I think they could make a point of being present and as he cannot be more than one place at a time each Day School could have the honour of having him in turn. But the idea is that Commencement Exercises should be the Annual Affair of the school year.

There is another matter that I would like to suggest to you before you go as a witness in Ottawa before the committee there studying the Indian Act. To you think that the various Day Schools in our reserves could be graded for the purpose of promotion for our Indian Day School teachers? It would be an incentive for the teacher and I think would raise the standard of our teachers and raise the standard of our schools as well. Of course the higher the grade of school the larger the salaries. (I believe you have that system in your Indian Agencies with regard to Indian Agents and Doctors).

I hope Sir, that you will not feel that I have gone out of bounds in making these suggestions to you, but I assure you that I honestly think our Day Schools could be improved.

I look forward to receiving the Indian School Bulletin every two months and of course I keep it on file as instructed but a proper file worthy of the high standard of this publication should be provided in my opinion.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) Ahab Spence

Dear Mr. Neary:

I am enclosing herewith a copy of my resignation as teacher of this school.

I am yet undecided whether or not I shall ever resume teaching again. I shall attempt to complete my Arts and if I decide to go back into teaching I shall get my Normal first. But I doubt whether I shall do that because of my age. Anyway I am staying on here as missionary, and will give my moral support to the new teacher if she needs it at any time.

As you probably know now the new teacher if accepted in Grade III category will be the most "certificated" teacher that this school has ever had. I know her personally, she was here before, and I would not hesitate to recommend her for any school in the world.

I strongly recommended qualified and certificated teachers for our Indian schools in my recent representation at Ottawa, and it is only fair that I as being one of those "uncertificated" teachers to make way for those that are, if and when we are fortunate enough to get them.

In closing may I suggest that my "Retirement Fund Withdrawal" for 1946-47 be returned to me as soon as possible because I need it for Summer School which commences on the first Wednesday in July.

Thanking you Sir, for your splendid cooperation and encouragement while in your service.

Yours Respectfully,

Ahab Spence.

You will recall that I wrote you on April 14 with regard to the addition of a second classroom at the above school.

Modification of the lunch-room should be restricted to transferring the existing full-size windows from the side opposite the entrance door to the other side.
